output: Mr. President, firstly, I would like to congratulate Mr. Sibep on the work done, as his report incorporates many of the concerns expressed in this chamber.
Focusing on these crucial issues for the entire European Union. These are water scarcity and drought, matters that have already ceased to be solely a problem of the countries in Southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections made in the opinion report, for which I was the rapporteur in the Agriculture Committee, in favor of agricultural activity, emphasizing, for example, the role played by farmers in the sustainable management of available resources.

It includes, likewise, a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that exacerbate prices in raw materials, an aspect in which I also consider it very important to point out in the current times, so that we bear in mind not only the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Environment Committee, moreover, included the idea of creating a European Drought Observatory, an action also mentioned in the report of the Agriculture Committee, and I hope that one day this will be reflected in concrete actions.

The text to be voted on tomorrow, however, incorporates a proposal made by the Agriculture Committee to examine the implementation of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to advocate for the establishment of this fund, an idea that I will once again propose to Parliament when it receives, in the coming months, the communication that the Commission plans to publish on adapting to climate change.

It seems to me that, following the establishment of the Solidarity Fund, which was created to mitigate the losses caused by climate-related disasters, it is now time to consider an instrument that acts a priori and is designed to finance preventive measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of such climate catastrophes.

Modulation is the central focus of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of Parliament's opinion to have any impact on the negotiations being conducted by the Union's Ministers of Agriculture.

At this juncture, the European Union is deciding the future of many farmers and livestock breeders, and I would particularly like to draw attention to vulnerable sectors such as sheep, cattle, and tobacco farming, whose survival in many production areas will depend on this health check.

Some producers, such as those in the sheep sector, are no longer asking for help; they simply want to be allowed to leave the market with dignity, because they have done the math and the only way to survive is to reduce production volumes.

The abandonment of production, therefore, is the only option left for many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be filled by imports from third countries, because the consumer will not stop consuming and the world will continue to increase the number of consumers at an unprecedented rate.
The Parliament should issue a prudent opinion, and the Council should heed it.

I believe that at this stage of the debate, it is crucial to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.

The common agricultural policy should not be the problem, but the solution. And for this, we need a strong first pillar.
We believe in and support rural development, but we do not think that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not a matter of strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that there is a need to simplify the single payment scheme, to review market instruments.

If we do this right, we will be laying the foundations for a common agricultural policy beyond 2013. If not, we will be putting an end to the activity of many European farmers.
We are facing a plan that has been greatly anticipated by the fruit-growing sector, not only due to the difficulties it is facing but also because of the concerning decline in consumption.
We are faced with a public health promotion plan. I believe it should be a European plan, and I also support full community funding.

I disagree with allowing parents to contribute to the co-financing, because the same old thing will happen. Parents who can contribute money will have their children consume fruits and vegetables in schools, while those who cannot will be left out of the program.
I believe it must be a community-funded plan for its distribution to be homogeneous.
Therefore, I also want to strongly emphasize that the focus should be on educational measures.

It is not merely about a student eating an apple, but knowing what kind of apple they are consuming. Understand its nutritional properties and comprehend the beneficial effects that such fruit has on their health and development.

Of course, these should be products with all quality guarantees, giving priority, if possible, to seasonal fruits and, whenever feasible, I advocate for the community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I believe that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I would like to congratulate the Commissioner, will be immediately noticeable. Of course, this will be for the present and future health of our children and their current education.

But I also believe that it is of great importance for the horticulture sector, a productive sector that constitutes a genuine European cultural heritage. For thanks to it, we can enjoy a balanced, healthy, and varied diet.
I believe it is worth betting on and investing in this fruit and vegetable distribution plan in our schools.
I believe the budget falls slightly short because I advocate for full community funding of such an ambitious plan as this one.

Mr. President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I wish to express the most vigorous condemnation by my group of the murders being committed in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or of a religion.

Specifically, the manner in which this atrocious murder was committed, we already know: a 13-year-old girl who is raped and then accused of adultery, and five men, if they can be called men, rush to stone her and even prevent anyone from trying to save her, in a stadium occupied by a thousand people.
This, coupled with the acts of piracy that have reached nearly 100 hijacked ships off the coast of Somalia this year, constitutes an absolutely unacceptable humanitarian situation.
The international community cannot remain indifferent to this.
It cannot remain impassive in the face of cowardice, in the face of religious invocation to commit atrocities.
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate government of Somalia in regaining control of the entire country and establishing a rule of law that respects human rights.
I believe that on few occasions have we been presented with a situation so clear and one that imposes such obligations upon us.
I do not believe that we can remain impassive in this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in that situation.
I don't know how it can be done, but I certainly believe that it must be done and that quick action is necessary.

pest and disease control affecting the cultivation of a large number of food products, specifically all Mediterranean products, as well as the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.

However, it is important to consider that the temporal definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the elimination of a large number of active substances, particularly insecticides, that are of key importance to agriculture.

Producers must have access to a sufficient quantity of active substances to effectively and safely combat any plant disease or pest, taking into account that the hazard is often not in the product itself, but rather in its misuse.
For all these reasons, the Spanish delegation of the PP-Edei Group... supports the proposals requesting an impact assessment... and will vote in favor of the amendments...
from Mr Stardi, which I myself have signed, concerning endocrine disruptors and those that facilitate the availability of plant protection products in emergency situations.

Furthermore, if this regulation is adopted as agreed, the effects will be a reduction in food production and a rise in prices, leading us to import the very same foods we cannot produce, treated with the very products we are producing.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Capato, your report is one that is filled with good intentions. The most evident proof is that it did not warrant any amendments during its processing in the Committee on Civil Liberties.
Were you yourself the one who introduced 18 amendments to your own report?
And those amendments are what have introduced into that report an added element of radicalism, let's say in general terms, which raises very serious doubts for me.

I would propose to divide the amendments you have put forward into four distinct categories. Amendments that you yourself have proposed, I insist, in a report that initially received the support of all groups.
Some are impossible. You are asking for things that are impossible.

For example, Mr. Capato, you are requesting things for which there is as yet no legal basis. For instance, until the Lisbon Treaty enters into force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of different committees.
Something similar was just told to you by Commissioner Wallström. Or you request, for example, that we declare 2009 the year of transparency. We are late, there is no more time.
Therefore, you are asking for things that are impossible.
Additionally, it requests some other features which are not recommended.
For example, you request transparency in the meetings of political groups.
No, sir, no.
Privacy is lacking, and privacy is a political good.
If I wish to disagree with my party, to maintain an opposition, I want to do so in private, and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency should be demanded of public institutions, but not within political parties where debates must be guaranteed in private.
Therefore, I cannot follow you on that point.
There are some other assertions you make, Mr. Capato, that are inaccurate.
For example, you say that 90% of legislative activity is pro-comitology.
That is a reckless exaggeration, Mr. Capato...
Moreover, climatology inherently entails rules of transparency.

If what we are going to do now is create more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be going against what we want to achieve, which is transparency—something that is very closely related to simplicity.
And lastly, before the president calls my attention, as I am already using up my time, there are some things that are unnecessary.

For example, I understand that it is very popular and very appealing to public opinion to talk about transparency in the activity of deputies, to let it be known that they attend the plenary sessions.
It is already known, Mr. Capato.
Or those that go to the committees, as is well known. If there is a record of all of them. These are acts accessible to all citizens.
Or the diets they charge for, as you well know, Mr. Capato.
In other words, it is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

Therefore, I understand that it is very popular with public opinion and that advocating for transparency is very appealing, but I want you to know that transparency means making things appear as they are. And when we contribute to things not being seen as they are, Mr. Capato, then we are not contributing to transparency.

Thank you, Madam President. Madam Commissioner, as we can see, in recent times the textile sector has been undergoing a significant crisis that has led to numerous company closures, offshoring, and unemployment, with these events particularly concentrated in regions specialized in this activity.

In light of the current economic crisis situation, the European Commission should act swiftly alongside the Member States to mitigate the socio-economic effects of this restructuring, which is particularly dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I believe it is necessary to provide support to workers in the textile and clothing sector through social measures, and through plans for companies that are subject to restructuring and are currently in serious difficulties.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial part of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to the restructuring and retraining of the textile sector.
in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, which make up the majority of the sector in the European Union and are most affected by the effects of market liberalization.

It is not at all about promoting trade barriers,

It is a matter of compensating for the negative effects of such a significant transformation. We must also remember that the European Union is the world's second-largest exporter of textile products and clothing made from vegetable fibers.

which makes it necessary to ensure the best conditions of access to the markets of third countries, essential for the future of the textile and clothing industry based in the European Union, and in particular for SMEs.

among other things, would involve subjecting imported products to the same safety and consumer protection requirements as those manufactured within the European Union.

One of these cases is that of the Basque language, Euskera, which is not a minority language but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which administratively falls within the Spanish state.

But the same does not happen, and do not take it personally, Commissioner, with Northern Basque Country, part of the French State, whose president, addressing the UN Assembly, asserts that denying respect for national identities and languages is fueling humiliation, and that without such respect there will be no peace in the world.
And then, neither Basque, nor Corsican, Breton or Occitan have the slightest official recognition or support to respect or promote their use.

Therefore, I call on the Fundamental Rights Agency to ensure and work towards the protection of the rights of the native language of every European people within the Member States, with no discrimination against their inhabitants, and for all these languages to be considered official within their respective territories.

Thank you, Madam President. Firstly, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his great work in achieving a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our House.
With this directive, we once again demonstrate our commitment to building a common migratory policy based on a comprehensive approach.
The approach of this directive is clear: to combat organized crime, punish unscrupulous employers, and protect exploited immigrants who lack any form of social protection.

We seek the elimination of unjust poverty wages for immigrants, which also depresses middle-class salaries, particularly in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, or hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and large amounts of money involved in the shadow economy.
In precisely difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently, with generosity but also with responsibility.
The easy option would be to give in to the temptation of not attempting to curb the shadow economy.
We cannot turn a blind eye and leave around eight million irregular immigrants in a state of vulnerability with working conditions akin to slavery.

Ladies and Gentlemen, if we want this directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic and even criminal sanctions in the most aggravated cases are necessary, which will have a dissuasive effect on entrepreneurs.
By doing so, we will manage to reduce the shadow economy and eliminate the migratory incentive created by the possibility of working illegally.
It must be made clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal route.
Therefore, we wish to pursue the global approach and call on the Commission, Commissioner, Mr Baró, to present the new "blue cards," as soon as possible, for the other employment categories.
Dear colleagues, Ms Ferrero-Waldner, Mr Solana, I would like to begin by thanking the three rapporteurs for their work, and as shadow rapporteur for the report on CSDP, I will address...
In this specific report, I begin by congratulating Mr. Sarisbolski on the outcome of his work and on the collaboration he has offered from other groups to achieve a consensual result.

In the same way that this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to be equipped with the necessary instruments to speak with one voice in the world, the Chamber itself is also capable of showing cohesion around the assessment and promotion of the major priorities in foreign policy and the common security policy.

Our group, the Socialist Group, has pursued a dual approach. On the one hand, we have sought to introduce or strengthen major issues that are, for us, key priorities across the entire realm of foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of

peace across the entire planet or a commitment to human development. On the other hand, to propose elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the CSDP as they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared at all, or to introduce them as a new element if they were absent.
In this way, we have advocated, for instance, for a greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the recently defined Eastern dimension.

We have advocated for greater diversification and enhanced relevance in our relations with Africa, a continent we often only remember when particularly vicious wars break out, and even then, not always.

In relation to Latin America, we have sought to reflect the current negotiation processes of association agreements, the first of a bioregional nature that the European Union will conclude in its entire history.

As for the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that only focuses on security, in order to instead include the entire rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained within the Barcelona Process.

As for amendments for the plenary session, our group has not tabled any, believing that the balance achieved through the compromises is thereby strengthened. Consequently, we will oppose most of the amendments to avoid undermining the agreement reached in the Foreign Affairs Committee. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. The Venezuelan referendum has resulted in a victory for the 'yes' vote, gracefully acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that there has not been equal opportunity in the campaign and that the ruling party has enjoyed overwhelming support from the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under those conditions, the country has been left practically divided into two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not through visceral attitudes, disparagement, or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralistic, and free path.
In that regard, we criticize the Venezuelan government's decision to expel a Spanish MEP, and even more so the manner in which such expulsion was carried out. But we call on this House to avoid...
that our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate local laws, let alone insult a head of state, however criticizable they may be.
With these attitudes, we are compromising future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.

Mr. President, I have just returned from Venezuela, where I was invited by its electoral authority as a member of an international electoral accompaniment group for the referendum held on the 15th of last month.

The European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council, providing an overall positive assessment of the process in terms of its organization, transparency, participation, the free and secret exercise of the right to vote, and security throughout all its stages.

On the contrary, it would be incumbent upon the honorable member to provide explanations to this House regarding an action that affects us all.

Council Recommendation of 28 May 2001 on cooperation between the judicial authorities of the Member States in the field of obtaining evidence in civil or commercial matters.
We are in a context that is truly not communal; it is an intergovernmental sphere, in which the Council, through regulations, has sought to stimulate cooperation among these judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union,

...that is, certain measures have been foreseen... for example, the issuance of practical guides... the use of electronic means... and so on. However, I acknowledge that it is quite difficult... for the Commission to take action...

I do not know what the Commission has achieved or intends to achieve, but it seems to me quite difficult to accomplish due to the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation presents.

In other words, we are asking judicial authorities to collaborate with each other; we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities handling 22 different languages, with legal systems that are very distinct from each other, and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a significant delay in these cooperation mechanisms, and certainly, we do not have the means to carry them out.
Ideally, one would have material resources,
For example, what could the Commission do to provide judicial bodies, especially those at a lower level, with technological tools such as a videoconferencing system?
Videoconferencing may be a utopian ideal for many small courts across the European Union, but it appears to be the only way to achieve this.
I believe that the European Union should rely on already existing institutions, specifically the European Judicial Network,
We would need to strengthen this institution so that judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, any training for judges is fundamental.
This is something the Commission cannot do on its own either.
However, the Commission can encourage the development of this type of training course in community law and in the knowledge of different legal systems.

Then there is a huge difficulty, which is the problem of languages, that is, how can communication be established, for example, between a Spanish judge and a Finnish judge, with two such different languages.
It is not reasonable to expect judges, in addition to having to navigate their own legal system, which is already quite complex in itself, to be required to have knowledge of this type of matter.
What can we do from a practical standpoint to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?
What could we do to assist them in accomplishing this?
in presenting this report, to exhibit any kind of rigor or harshness towards the Commission.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislative term with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a major maritime accident, that of the Erika vessel, near the French coast, which gave its name to an initial set of legislative proposals aimed at halting and preventing accidents.
We believed we had averted the danger, but soon after, the coasts of Galicia were ravaged by the oil slick from another accident, even greater than the first, involving the personal vessel.

Since then, in the Transport Committee, we have been working on successive legislative packages, attempting to overcome the numerous resistances we encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States that rejected our proposals, considering them too demanding.

In these ten years, we have adopted various directives and regulations, some of which we have had to revise again because, due to the cuts promoted by the Council, they were not effective in their original formulation.

We approved the rules for the introduction of double-hulled vessels, the European Fund for Oil Pollution Prevention and Control, and refuge ports. Now we are reviewing and approving the liability of passenger sea carriers and the investigation of matters.

maritime accidents, the community system for tracking and information on maritime traffic, port state control, and finally, the regulation and directive concerning ship inspection and recognition organizations.
And all of this is good and desirable to be able to enter into force and be applied by all member states in the shortest possible timeframe.
That is why I feel satisfied.
But the legislative term ends, I leave Parliament, and I do so with the regret of not having succeeded in making the introduction of existing control systems mandatory.
are patented to know when and how many bilge and fuel tank residues have been illegally discharged into the sea by a particular ship.
That is, a kind of black boxes or tachometers that can be inspected by maritime authorities each time a ship arrives in port.

I believe we owe the marine environment better care and stricter procedures to curb the vast amount of pollution we produce. If we fail to do so, it will impact our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that it will not take another 10 years to control illegal marine spills more effectively and efficiently.
President, the review of the Novilla Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and affects us all, especially the peripheral countries, which feel victimized by this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to tackle the internationalization of external costs in road transport by introducing three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

While the principles inspiring the proposal, "he who uses pays" and "he who pollutes pays," are reasonable, the proposed solution is not, as it will be discriminatory towards a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing road freight transport, even if it was not the intention, has turned out to be the outcome.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is ill-timed and, far from achieving the desired goals of sustainable transport, would be a death sentence for a large number of European small and medium-sized enterprises that employ thousands of people.

people in the European Union who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their end consumer. A consumer who will see how their products become more expensive due to the application of these tariffs.

Ladies and gentlemen, we need a competitive, sustainable, and environmentally-friendly transport system, without overlooking the road network, because currently it is the only way to reach everywhere.
Modal change remains a dream, far from becoming a reality.
Trans-European networks, motorways of the sea, cross-border connections remain in some cases projects and not reality.
Ladies and Gentlemen, when the Titanic of the global economy is sinking, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to keep playing, let alone for joys.

The European Commission, on July 15, 2008, adopted a communication addressed to the Council and the Parliament, recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European Council on Foreign Relations recognized Mexico as a strategic partner on October 13th, pending the opinion of the Parliament on the matter.
Let us recall that already at the seventh meeting of the Joint Parliamentary Committee European Union-Mexico, held at the end of October last year, we stated that a
The strategic association between Mexico and the European Union constitutes a necessary impetus to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We highlight the good moment in relations between both parties and the positive balance of the current comprehensive agreement.

We emphasize the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and cooperation matters, especially in the face of the new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis that is shaking our continents.

With the great country that Mexico is, we share values and goals such as the development of democratic forms of government, commitment to gender equity, consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.
We advocate for closer cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking, based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Accordingly, we are going to support the proposal for recommendations on the European Union's Strategic Partnership with Mexico, which will be put before Parliament this very morning.

which has been a success in many developing countries, including some European ones, both as an economic activity mechanism and as a tool to improve social inclusion and job creation.

the European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate this access and which should be included in the report.

Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Bocland has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the ship recycling convention to be held in May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr Bloch, not only for the question but also for the resolution he has prepared.

In the Popular Party, we are in favor of the fight against the bad practices and methods that have been used to thin out ships, and therefore we support Mr. Brokland's resolution proposal. However, there are some points that concern us.

The first is paragraph 3, which he has also highlighted, stating that ships in their entirety should be considered hazardous waste and, consequently, should fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have tabled an amendment on this paragraph because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union, and we believe that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradicted. However, it should be the future international agreement on ship dismantling that defines the details of its implementation.
The proposed resolution also calls for, in point 14, a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

It seems to us to be somewhat premature to discuss mandatory contributions at this time when the system to be adopted for this financing has not yet been decided within the IMO. And I also believe that the European Commission does not have a clear answer on this matter.
Finally, in point 15, the commission is urged to clearly establish that the state with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible state.
We believe it is within the Commission's purview to decide on this matter, which should also be resolved in an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure coherence between the future convention on ship recycling and the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal, taking into account not only the Basel Convention but also all existing legislation.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is to congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we share a great deal of agreement on this program, and to congratulate us all because in times of economic crisis, it is fundamental to maintain a program like this one, with clear positive social effects.

Although we are faced with a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that, at this time of economic uncertainty, Brussels and Strasbourg are not exclusively concerned or

not only concerned with the recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those that support those most in need, the poorest in the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program should continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy. Here we agree with the commission. Not only because European agriculture has a strong social character, but also because it is a functioning instrument, because it is now needed more than ever, and because it must continue to function.

From the Socialist Group, like the rapporteur, we oppose the co-financing of this program between the European Union and the Member States, as it would imply discrimination among states based on their wealth, potentially resulting in the program not being implemented in the most needy countries.

It is not understood why, at a time when it is most needed, the Commission seeks to save Community funds in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budget surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full community funding is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries, especially those most in need.
43 million potential beneficiaries of this program demand a greater effort from us and, in no case, that budget expenditure be spared.
Austerity, yes, but not at the expense of the poorest.
And it is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizen of all the Member States that the program must cover the entire journey of the food distributed.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have tabled an amendment to ensure that all expenses arising from distribution, including transport, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the rapporteur that food should preferably be community-sourced and of high quality.
This is the stance consistent with the position taken by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this House, such as the fruit distribution plan in schools.
Nothing more, and many thanks.

We hope that the Commission will take into account the position of this Parliament when the vote takes place and, above all, that the plan will be implemented in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile areas of our planet.
The consequences of unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The melting of vast areas has brought these risks to the forefront, making it necessary to establish new global regulations to protect the Arctic, similar to those already in place for Antarctica, while considering the differences that have been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty among all involved parties, undoubtedly including the European Union, is necessary to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable character of all types of human activities, and multilaterally regulate navigation through the new maritime routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, throughout its many years of existence, has been a model of cooperation in addressing shared challenges.

At this time of difficulties and uncertainty, we must raise that spirit and that harmony to higher levels to prevent the states in the region or other international actors from engaging in geopolitical disputes, forgetting what should be the common goal: the preservation of a great shared heritage.

Madam President, for once I am glad that the President is not here, and that Mr Tajani has come, because Mr Tajani has the advantage of having been a Member of the European Parliament.
And as a European Parliamentarian, I know that you have experienced the frustration that we European Parliamentarians feel regarding the implementation of Community law.

Now, in Parliament, we tend to criticize the Commission. I believe we are asking the Commission for an impossible task, because all Community law and the entire application of Community law are based on indirect application.

In other words, the Commission has only a handful of officials at its headquarters where it receives some complaints and has some scope for action. However, at this time, there is also a tendency to limit budgetary powers, which means the Commission will not have the ability to act.
All Community law, the entire application of Community law, is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, and national officials.
And here, in this regard, I do not think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we need to do is assist the Commission. And I believe that in Mrs. Frazzoni's report there are some points that could be useful in achieving this implementation.
I am referring to those concerning the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments, and the action of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, during a mission led by my companion, my group colleague present here, Marían, I had the opportunity to visit.
and for being present in this court and for being aware of the immense work this court was undertaking, not just for Sierra Leone, but for all of humanity.
The Special Court for Sierra Leone, as has already been mentioned here, has undoubtedly set a precedent.

A precedent because, as the resolution rightly points out, it is the first internationally funded tribunal through voluntary contributions, the first court established in the country where the alleged crimes took place, and also, as already mentioned, the first tribunal to try a former prime minister.

For all these reasons, not only because it sets a precedent, but also because it serves as a reference for other courts established in its wake, such as those in Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, Cambodia, and Lebanon, we deem it essential that this resolution be adopted. We have been working on it jointly with the court for several months now.
Two years ago, we adopted a resolution to support its funding. Two years ago, the court was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of decisions.
...and it did not have sufficient support. Here, we must also thank the European Commission... ...for providing financial support, so to speak, for this court.

Now we are asking for two things above all. Firstly, that the individuals convicted serve their sentences. What is at stake is not just the operation of the court which ends next year, but the legacy this court will leave us. And secondly, obviously, all of this must be accompanied by increased funding.
In definitive, the Special Court for Sierra Leone is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have tried war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and it is a lesson being taught by the second poorest country on this planet, where upon entering the court, we saw a motto written that read, "Without justice, there is no peace."
And precisely for that reason, we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans but as human beings, to ensure that the legacy of this court remains permanently in history.

Mr. President, I believe that the draft regulations submitted to us by the committee are important and necessary. Moreover, it was also important and necessary that, from the outset,
European Parliament, we insisted on the principles emphasized by the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, Mr. Zivieska and Mr. Depré, which is the principle of Community competence.

This is a matter of shared competence between the Community and the Member States, where, for practical reasons, it is advisable to maintain certain competences of the States, but as Mr. Barró has stated, these should be limited in scope and duration.
Community competence is non-negotiable, and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor Parliament have the authority to relinquish these community competencies.

With this established, it is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, and which I think will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow for the adoption of this package of measures at first reading.

Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, I have signed this resolution and requested to speak on this matter because I was a witness to what was called an expulsion, but in reality was the kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrero.

Furthermore, I was able to verify that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of opponents, threats, contempt for the dignity of individuals, and the tortuous use of justice, among other things, are common practices in Venezuela.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel's back and has led to this resolution. But there are thousands of cases as egregious as his that are cited in the resolution and others that are not.
such is the case of the Ocedeño son, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well-known for its danger and also because it elected a mayor who was not from the Chavista regime.

Eligio studied thanks to the support of others, and specifically Citibank, which enabled him to found his own business, the Banco de Caracas. Moreover, he later lived a normal life, assisting those most in need.
Today, however, he languishes in a Caracas prison, illegally, after two years of detention without any formal charges.
Their only crime, being part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Niso Moreno, student leader at the University of the Andes, elected several times to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
In 2003, he won the elections to the Federation against the current Minister of Interior and Justice. And this is his crime.
Today he is accused of attempted homicide, lewd and violent acts, and all of this despite having been exonerated of all charges.

Situations like yours are an everyday occurrence in this country where the persecution of opponents, with the intent to exclude them from political life and discourage dissent, has become a part of daily life.

However, from here, it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy despite the difficulties. I am certain that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be removed from office through the ballot box.

in cases where states lacked them. But assuming that this is not a problem exclusive to southern European states, and that climate change does not only affect certain states, but rather all of them, it is a common cause.

decisive actions to maximize the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, as they are evidently at the root of wildfires, their causes, and subsequently, the causes of further climate change.

But for that challenge to be met by the committee, if indeed, Commissioner, you wish to prevent the South of the Union, which does exist, from continuing to burn.
Mr. President, thank you very much for granting me the floor. I address Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have been following you with great interest and deep respect for a long time, since you were a leader in a country that is very close to us and dearly loved, namely Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that now you have me absolutely astonished.

I am surprised for two reasons. Firstly, because you have shown contempt towards the group I belong to, the Non-Attached Members, by not granting us a single minute of your time to come and share your political proposals with us.
We represent many European citizens, and you have shown contempt for all our voters.
Secondly, due to the fragility of its political project and the poverty of its political proposals in the document "Political Guidelines for the Next Commission."
Some proposals that fall short of even reflecting the positions you have upheld throughout your own term as President of the Commission.
I have been surprised in this regard that issues such as energy, which have been well addressed throughout your term, now, when you present us with your proposals for the next...

Madam Commissioner, you concluded your remarks by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began by saying that you had already taken all the necessary measures and that the situation was being resolved.
Look, to correct is the mark of wisdom.
And that is a Spanish saying that could be very aptly applied to the case that concerns us today.

The dairy sector has been suffering for months from one of the most severe crises in its history. Despite this, due to the refusal to yield, either by the European Commission or by certain governments, including what appears to be my own, the Spanish government, they deny reversing the decisions of the Health Check of the CAP.
These decisions were made without considering the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that emerged after that commitment was closed.
It seems that the Member States either did not want to or could not see the storm that was brewing at the time.
The reform became outdated in a short time due to the significant shift in the market, a change that demonstrates the sector's complete vulnerability to price volatility.

That major producers such as France and Germany, countries that achieved, in absolute terms, the largest increase in their national production quotas under that agreement, are now the ones calling for a review of the check-up's decisions, gives much cause for thought.

In my understanding, the Member States were mistaken and should have listened more attentively to the voices, mine included, that called for postponing any definitive decision on the future of the sector until 2011.
A shame they didn't listen to us.
Do it now.
Mr. President, this Parliament is the palace of chimeras, it is the palace of dreams.
The Irish people, with their strong vote, give us the encouragement and strength to continue thriving and to build a strong Europe, and above all, a federal Europe.
Only then would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs to the fathers of Europe, whose work brought us all here.

Mr. President, having overcome the unease caused by the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, it is time, in my view, to consider how to address nationalist attitudes that so hinder European construction in the future.
My idea is that these obstructions cannot come without cost.
With a clear mind, it is time to consider the possible measures to be taken in the days and years ahead.
This modest representative wishes for a future President of the Council who is a man, or better yet, a woman, convinced of European federalism, and who wields the necessary authority.
which is located in the Schengen area and which is identified and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

The breakdown of the constitutional order in Honduras ends two decades without coups in Latin America and sets a perverse precedent for other countries, especially the weakest ones, as is now the case with Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and silent in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting President Arias' mediation in line with the position adopted unanimously by the OAS with the backing of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president, Micheletti, has breached the recently reached agreements, mocking the international community and preventing, among other measures, the return of the duly elected president, Mr. Zelaya.

Under the current circumstances, the election of a new president in the elections scheduled for November 29th suffers from a lack of legitimacy from its inception, and its results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would commit a serious error if it were to send a delegation to observe the elections, as this would be interpreted as an endorsement of the coup d'état. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament is characterized by being a guarantor of freedom, democracy, the rule of law, and respect for human rights.
As Bacla Havel stated this morning, there cannot be two weights or two measures.
We are all democrats here and, consequently, freedom fighters. And therefore, whether we speak of Cuba, China, North Korea, or now Honduras, our discourse must be steadfast in defense of freedom.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preferences.
There are no right-wing or left-wing coup plotters or dictators, only freedom-killers and oppressors.

Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change, and as a result, a very dangerous precedent will have been set. The doctrine of the "good," "temporary," and "not-too-obvious" coup will have prevailed.

I would like to congratulate the members of the Committee on Petitions, and its chair, Mr Leine, on the work they have done to enable us to have a resolution such as the one we have, which we must approve unequivocally.
We can settle for now by speaking of having enough with sectoral agreements, because talking about a patchwork agreement is already admitting to a part of the failure.
We must go to approve this resolution, which has three noble aspirations.
A more evident one, that of avoiding climate change, with concrete proposals for reducing emissions and with a commitment to funding, aiming for a binding agreement, I mean, not a patchwork one.

And two latent aspirations. One, to start sooner rather than later to work towards having a common energy policy, as we once endowed ourselves with a common agricultural policy because it was necessary. And, of course, the other is to regain the trust of citizens in politics and politicians, of which we do not have an abundance in Europe.
In that regard, the success of the summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
Therefore, I encourage the acting President of the Council to maintain his optimism, to apply pressure and negotiate as much as possible to bring others on board for this success.

I do not know if the leaders of this multipolar world wish to be called into question by history for their inability to reach a binding agreement. But as a representative and, I believe, all representatives of the people, we cannot be called into question by history for failing to secure the binding commitment we have to humanity in Copenhagen to avert climate change.

Today, there is no doubt about the European Union's commitment to the fight against terrorism, and thanks to the Stockholm Treaty and the Stockholm Program, we will continue to make progress in this area of freedom, justice, and security, which is so necessary.

But in my view, this struggle has been based on mutual trust among member states. However, it is high time, with the possibilities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon, to harmonize national legislations towards not prescribing terrorist offenses, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this happens, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has happened, happens, and may continue to happen, to the detriment of terrorism victims, who see those who murdered their loved ones treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore call on this Parliament to promote or adopt the European Charter of Victims' Rights in Terrorism, based on the defense of human memory.

Thank you, Madam President. Firstly, I would like to congratulate Ms. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in addressing international food supply needs.

Now that the European Commission appears to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the community budget, it must be said loudly and clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food self-sufficiency should be. And in past decades, it has been seen that without the CAP, food self-sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture, therefore, cannot be compared to other sectors of the economy that are able to thrive in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to move their business forward, and the Union in turn needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizenry.
I believe, therefore, that there should be a change of direction in the CAP, but it should not disappear.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to ensure direct aid to farmers, as well as reestablish a policy for managing agricultural markets that provides greater price stability. This would benefit not only farmers, but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to foster balanced relationships among the different actors in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
Furthermore, there is a need for a consumer information policy for Europeans that highlights the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union environmental regulations.
environment, food safety, and animal welfare, because community producers have to compete with productions from third countries where much lower standards are applied to these imports.

And these producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply their own domestic markets due to a genuine issue of profitability, with the backing of WTO negotiations.
According to a United Nations report, in 2009 approximately 270,000 people were victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary for the action of the European Union to be primarily based on the protection of victims, with special attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to attend indifferently to this theater, to this spectacle of sexual exploitation that is unfolding before our eyes.
That is why I fully support this Parliament's request for victim support to be unconditional, more robust, and with harsher penalties, as Mr Barrot has just told us.
With that said, I would like to request that the President and the Council use all European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European Protection Order for Victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the Stockholm Programme debates and which has finally been brought to light, will be an effective instrument in the fight against these crimes.

And I expect a firm commitment, as we have already seen, from the Spanish Presidency for this order to provide victims with special protection measures that are effective across the entire territory of the European Union.

I hope that those of us with the responsibility to act on the most serious problems in our society provide a real and concrete response to this extremely grave issue of human trafficking, and that we do not merely content ourselves with fine words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr. Zapatero, for a Spaniard such as myself, it is an honor to greet your presence here in your capacity as President of the European Union.
There are high expectations and challenges during this period, and of course, we cannot disappoint the expectations generated.
May citizenship perceive our renewed institutions as instruments capable of providing solutions to real problems.
The program outlined by your lordship is known to be shared by us.

For the People's Party of Spain, this is a matter of national importance, and we will support your honor in all areas that we believe represent common interests for Europe and are significant for Spain.
It is an ambitious program, and one that I hope will be filled with content.

I would like for people to be able to see, in that album of the Spanish presidency, that each event marks a milestone in addressing real issues that affect them, as it will surely be colorful and diverse.
The crisis strikes economies, and unemployment seems like a fifth horseman of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to acknowledge that 20% unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not incapacitate you.
...what I believe is that it obligates us all to produce... a solution or problem that we truly have to solve together...
that is a real problem.
Time does not permit me to say much, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain has many challenges ahead. I believe, I am certain of Spain's capabilities as a nation. And I want to believe, and I am sure, that you will rise to the occasion for our country.

We cannot disappoint, at this crucial hour for Europe, these expectations. On the other hand, the globalized world, and this has been intelligently acknowledged, leads to the emergence of new power centers, and it is necessary for the European Union to play a more active and coherent role in defense of its values and interests.
Otherwise, we risk becoming irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, Spaniards do not accept that anyone should question our ability to make proposals.
We possess that legitimacy.
What we also need to have is the humility to accept those pieces of advice that Sancho gave to Don Quixote, when he recommended humility to him in the daydream of governing the island of Barataria.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has not ceased to surprise European women with highly innovative and progressive measures.
Of course, the formation of a truly egalitarian government and the courageous manner in which she has brought issues of gender equality and respect for others to the national and European agenda.
Mr. President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious program of action, of course, against gender-based violence, which is a social scourge.
The establishment of a European Observatory on Gender-Based Violence is a cutting-edge proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Portuguese socialists, I wish you good luck.
You can count on our solidarity.
women with Zapatero.
Mr. President, thank you. In a matter as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to unfold before taking action.
We should anticipate this, but we do not.
And unfortunately, we are advancing at the rate of failed attacks like the recent attempted attack in Detroit, which today compels us to make decisions that ensure the safety of air transportation.
Destroying body scanners in airports is a responsibility we cannot shirk, ladies and gentlemen.
We cannot keep waiting because terrorists do not wait.
Therefore, the commission must assure us as soon as possible that the dignity and privacy of individuals will be preserved and that there will be no negative health effects.
With this guarantee in place, we must adopt decisions for the entire European Union,

And to those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I will say that there is no higher right than the right to live. And those of us who love freedom above all, need to live in safety to truly feel free.

In that strong Europe, it is likely that the expression "improving coordination" will have to be dispensed with, as it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and strictly speaking refers to paralysis and indecision.
We know that the public finances and debts of European countries will continue to suffer until progress is made towards European financial integration and eurobonds are issued.

In any case, European institutions can already take concrete actions. I will not dwell on the rhetoric of coordination. And here we have, on the one hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision and, on the other hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision.
Good evening. I wish to state that I have not come to this Parliament to applaud the newly enacted law in Spain on abortion.

What concerns me is human life, and I am concerned about everything. I am here to defend women whose lives are at risk due to gender-based violence and to offer them a space where they can live freely and safely.

This Parliament's resolution of 2 February 2006 recommends that Member States adopt a zero-tolerance approach to all forms of violence against women and take the necessary measures to ensure better protection for victims.
The Stockholm Program, adopted by this House, established a space of freedom, justice, and security for all European citizens, and it prioritized the fight against gender-based violence,

In it, my request to the Spanish Presidency was reflected to promote, during its term, a European Protection Order for Victims of Gender-Based Violence, in order to ensure that victims of these crimes have the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a borderless Europe, the fight against gender-based violence should likewise know no borders, and member states should strive to harmonize their legislations so that the struggle against abuse of women transcends national boundaries.

legislative obstacles and, in the end, we could offer, at least within the European Union, we could protect the lives of women and their children. I therefore call on the Commission and the Council to do everything in their power to achieve this.

it is necessary and within their power to ensure the success of this European Protection Order for Victims, which is a highly effective tool in the fight against impunity for those who do not respect women's dignity or their right to live freely and safely.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy put an end to the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which once resonated with such hope and illusion among the peoples of the world, especially the most promising segments of international youth.
What characterizes, however, at this moment the dictatorship of the Castro brothers is the cruelty towards political and conscientious prisoners, the cruelty against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco in his death throes, with his mistreatment of political prisoners whom he also considered common criminals. His same obsessive contempt for exiles.
Castro ends up like Franco and all enemies of freedom when they entrench themselves in power.
But we must save lives and stand in solidarity with those who fight and suffer.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Thank you, Madam President. Mr. President of the Council, Commissioner, never again, never again should we allow our silence to become complicity with those who seek to restrict our freedoms.
Never again allow a person who fought for their rights and those of all to die in a Cuban prison or anywhere else without our strong and firm voice demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old black construction worker, who merely demanded the improvement of prison conditions, died after 86 days of hunger strike and 7 years in prison for advocating respect for human rights.
And during those seven years, he was mistreated, humiliated, and degraded by his jailers, all while the international community, it must be remembered, remained in a thick silence.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, such as psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Madam/Sir, the resolution we are presenting today, which we are debating today, and which we will vote on tomorrow, and which I represent on behalf of the Social Democrat Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
once again voice their support for a democratic transition and the strict observance of fundamental human rights.
Let us not delve into a divisive issue at this moment regarding whether or not to maintain the common position.
Let us focus on the issue at hand, that of saving lives and human rights.
And we are referring to a period of serene reflection in which we seek common ground on the issues of future politics with Cuba.
But this text also has an important added value.
The fact that it is presented by six political groups reflects a new era of broad consensus in this House on the issue of human rights.

Let it never again be asserted that European democratic right-wingers bow to the so-called orders of Yankee imperialism. But also, let it never again be said that social democrats are complacent or complicit with communist dictatorships.
Simply because both statements are false, and the victims of those who seek to restrict freedom, wherever they are, should know that we will stand united in the unconditional defense of their cause.

Mr. President, lastly, I would like to thank Mr. Salafranca, who negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Mrs. Weber from the Alliance of Democrats and Liberals Group, and Mr. Rodríguez.

On behalf of the Greens Group, to Mr Karsutnik from the Conservatives and Reformists, and to other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated, but I hope tomorrow successful endeavor.

And lastly, I would also like to thank the Spanish Prime Minister and President-in-Office of the European Union, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in advancing this resolution that we are debating today.
"History will absolve me" was the famous plea of a young lawyer that moved his people.
History absolves him of the effects of his rebellion against tyranny and later against the American blockade.
But with the same emphasis, this Parliament, which represents the largest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship that
endured by the people of Cuba, the violation of human rights on the island, the impiety towards political prisoners, the disdain for their exiled nationals.
The judgment of history is clear.
With this resolution, deputies from all ideologies stand in solidarity with the Cubans who are fighting.
Every possible effort must be made to avoid the brutal repression they endure, even surpassing the paralyzing so-called common position.
I pay homage to the poet Raúl Rivero in the final verse of his Havana. Do not impose taxes on affection, emptiness, suffocation, bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are safe.
Calm down, colleagues.
We're leaving now.
This week, International Women's Day was celebrated.
In this Parliament, we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union stating that yes, it is possible to end violence against women.

Today, we are discussing violence in Mexico, and it seems pertinent to acknowledge that Mexican women, both indigenous and non-indigenous, are among the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the army or police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, thus far, the responses of Mexican authorities have been ineffective, and thus, it is accurate to speak of nearly complete impunity.
Our resolution calls on the Mexican government to combat feminicides, a harsh but accurate term, given that almost all murders committed against women go unpunished.
An example is the State of Mexico, where in the last four years, only 11% of the criminals who murdered nearly 700 women were convicted.
At the same time, it appears that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible for two indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, to be sentenced to 21 years in prison and even
now more than three years have passed in prison, after six men from the Federal Investigative Agency were convicted of kidnapping the sole women during an incident at a market.
research. Hopefully, the judge, who will decide on the appeal in this case within a week, will realize the absurdity and injustice of the situation. But violence against women starts at home.

I hope that Mexican legislators will very soon improve the General Law on Women's Access to a Life Free of Violence so that it defines the types of violence and the mechanisms that make the rules operational.
Similarly, it would be standard to establish that domestic violence and marital rape are criminal offenses.
Furthermore, in order for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that in schools this issue becomes a central matter in the education of young people.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do this evening is to thank Mr. Escotá for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a true pleasure to work with him and with the other spokespersons of the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated tomorrow in the vote in this European Parliament, and we are proud of a stance like this one that upholds quality, promotes development, and enhances the value of rural areas, not just from an environmental perspective.

not merely testimonials of a traditional European culture, but as true generators of wealth and employment. Employment that is so desperately needed now, in these times of economic crisis and the dramatic employment situation in some Member States.
We also appreciate the stance maintained by this European Parliament and the position already clearly articulated by the Agriculture Committee, which is to prioritize quality to the highest degree.
And to that maximum extent, of course, we bet on maintaining that differentiation between designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Of course, we reject the idea of lowering quality standards, and we advocate for attention to be focused on community production, with its value being recognized and enhanced.
I welcome Commissioner Cholo's words.
It was certainly a pleasure to listen to him, to hear him speak about the commitment to the future of European agriculture.
Certainly, we hope that you will heed the voice of this Parliament, which will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

And finally, I would like to state that we hope that the European Commission never again preempts this Parliament by banning things such as, for example, the marketing standards for fruit and vegetables, which have caused so much harm to European free competition.
We seek to rectify market imbalances and also to invest in quality, diversity, food security, and an appropriate level of production.
We also want community productions and the quality of those community agro-food productions to be defended at the World Trade Organization.
And for that, of course, we also rely on the work of Commissioner Cholos, because our producers and European consumers cannot remain defenseless.
Thank you, President. The Commissioner has spoken about the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us therefore be consistent.
We have lost too many opportunities, too many treaties to introduce Community competence over European airspace.
But if we could not intervene as we should in heaven, we can on the skin of the earth.
for instance, by monitoring passengers' rights and also mediating or calling for a truce in the various collective conflicts in land transport,
No minimum services. Maximum services to all parties.
Thank you very much, President.
The procedure, electoral systems, and the election of Members of the European Parliament present problems. This means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

which was a mandate already contained in the Treaties of Rome. And for that reason, the coordinators, and I would like to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to all of them, but especially to Mr Jauregui and Mr Duff, have agreed on an appropriate amendment.

Tomorrow the vote will take place, and I hope that this House will support you precisely so that we can resolve this issue, this question of a uniform electoral procedure advised to the European Parliament, in the near future.
I believe that by doing so, we would eliminate this type of question.
In his address, Mr Traskowski spoke of the necessary representativeness of this House. And this is a factor that most speakers, Vice-President Sefcovich among them, have highlighted.
I agree, and we state this in the report of Article 1, that all 18 should enter as a block, because if they did not, we would lose representativeness.

And to ensure they enter as a bloc, to fulfill this act of political justice that is the Lisbon agreement, we, Your Honor, must be pragmatic because a transitional and exceptional situation also requires transitional and exceptional situations or solutions.

And therefore, I do not hide it, I do not like the possibility that this Chamber may be joined by deputies who were not elected in the 2009 elections. I state this clearly in paragraph 2, but if I have to choose between that and their non-entry...

either before the age of 18 or to seek a pragmatic solution so that it comes into effect before the age of 18 and we thus comply with the Lisbon Agreement. Therefore, I ask this House, and this is why I have presented this report, to opt for this transitional, pragmatic solution, but above all, Madam President, a fair one.
Many thanks to everyone for their collaboration and for the interesting contributions they have made to this work.

As I was unable to do so on March 11th, the International Day of Remembrance of and Tribute to the Victims of Terrorism, I would like to pay them a well-deserved tribute from this Parliament today, one that recognizes the immense sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to begin work on a directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the ones forgotten, and endure the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their tormentors.
It is high time that these European institutions recognize the dignity of victims of terrorism and assist them in their right to protection and justice, which should soon be translated into law.

that will honor all those who make it possible, and that the first article be that support for victims of terrorism be recognized as the right to justice, and that no government ever pay a political price.

I appeal to all who can defend the victims never to forget that true peace is born of justice, and it is the only peace that those of us who believe in justice must defend, from Europe and from anywhere in the world.

It has been necessary, Mr. President, for us to stand before the abyss and economic collapse for heads of state and government to understand that the path is not one of more nationalism, but of more Europe.
In this direction, measures adopted such as the decline of the right of veto in the European Council or the seed of a European public treasury are circulating.
Finally, albeit belatedly, we have realized that we are all in the same boat and that it is futile to address individual situations, especially in an improvised manner.

But I wonder whether this attitude is a parenthesis or, on the contrary, the beginning of a true European economic government. Because what is in excess, dear colleagues, is governance, and what is lacking is genuine government, if we wish to remain faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

Therefore, from this Parliament, we must promote all those reforms aimed at strengthening Europe and making budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, while setting aside, of course, nostalgic notions of sovereignty.
Colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and strengthening this Parliament is the only sure recipe for building a Europe that would otherwise fade away like a fleeting shadow.
Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, from the INTA Committee, thank you to Ms. Desarnet for the collaboration we have had.
Today more than ever, unity for the Mediterranean, the strengthening of major projects, and institutional development are necessary.
Today more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to the exit from the crisis, research, climate change, water, new energy models, and sustainable development.

And to achieve this, it is necessary to promote and conclude commercial and economic relations in the region, with short- and long-term measures. Free trade zone, elimination of tariff barriers, opening of the North-South and South-South market.

The Barcelona Summit, the Spanish Presidency, will provide the opportunity for a new commitment, a new situation, a new sharing of information, and the democratization of economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona Summit can position us to lead the Mediterranean.
Thank you, Madam President. Within the trans-European transport corridors is the railway corridor known as the Mediterranean Corridor.
It is a vital communication link that will connect North Africa with Europe.
For Spain, this axis is vital as it is a priority, since it would connect Algeciras with Europe...
not excluding other priority corridors, would pass through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community, and Catalonia.

...it opened up the possibility of communicating with various ports in the Mediterranean region...

Therefore, if we enhance the scope of a strategic railway axis across the Mediterranean, we will increase competitiveness for Spain and competitiveness for Europe.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Spanish rotating presidency on the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the
common position on Cuba and to establish a new type of relationship between the European Union and Cuba, which would naturally include, as a priority issue, the defense of human rights.
That policy has not been crowned with success, basically due to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship, which began this presidency precisely in January of this year.

this year with the expulsion of the representative addressing you, when attempting to visit the island with all the necessary visas and legal documentation to inquire about its human rights situation.
