Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues, this is a regulation of utmost importance for consumers and the agri-food industry, because it is by no means easy to achieve a balanced labeling that includes all essential information, yet is not so exhaustive as to complicate the message.
This is an excellent report, and the author deserves congratulations.
I agree with her on the major issues concerning nutritional information and the controversial matter of profiles, especially considering that the Commission failed to
commitment to establish said profiles, as well as their conditions of use, before January 19, 2009, as prescribed by Regulation 19-24-2006.

There is an issue that concerns me, and that is the possibility of coexistence with national labeling standards, as it goes against the very objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and the elimination of all possible barriers to the functioning of a genuine single market.
Regarding the indication of the country of origin, current legislation stipulates that this information must be provided when, in the event of omission, it could mislead the consumer.
Moreover, it is envisaged that there will always be a voluntary labeling system...
Going further could incur economic costs and administrative complexity for companies without providing any clear significant benefit to the consumer.
And regarding the use of different languages... I must say that the commission's proposal... aligns with the existing directive... which has worked well, and has not presented any issues.
Reopening this debate may prove both dangerous and necessary, potentially causing issues for the producer's circulation.
Mr. President. The best evidence of the good will we have is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the committee to the plenary.

But in addition to good will, I believe that we must be practical when labeling foods if we do not want to achieve the opposite effect of what we are pursuing. That is, to confuse the consumer instead of helping them to get informed.
It is not about illustrating, but about preventing, informing them about what they can eat and to what extent.
measure. It is necessary to label regarding fats, regarding sugars, regarding trans fats,
Indeed.
...which indeed focus on cholesterol-related issues...on all those substances that impact what we have discussed...on obesity and the health of individuals...

Yes, but some other foods with additional information such as place of origin, when it does not lead to confusion, or for example in a piece of meat, that is, the place of birth, place of passage, grazing area, and the place of slaughter, can be very illustrative, but they may end up confusing people.

It is up to us to ensure that we are practical and that this regulation becomes the one that harmonizes and informs consumers, or otherwise, it will be the one that causes more confusion and imposes issues that, far from achieving better health outcomes, will lead to greater degrees of confusion.

That is why I request, for example, that some of us opt for the GDA (Guideline Daily Amount), the daily intake amount, instead of traffic light labeling. Because it is very clear that if you consume this amount or twice as much, you will gain weight. Therefore, consume only one.
The amount of daily intake versus other types of codes is what some of us propose, in order not to further confuse the consumer.
Many thanks, Mr. Martín Fragueiro, for being here on behalf of the Spanish Presidency for a report such as this. Madam Commissioner,
Mr. Milana, congratulations on the ability to reach a common agreement, to bring together all interests, and to present an initiative report, one of the first initiative reports, on the table.
The takeoff of aquaculture is important.

It is necessary due to the increase in fish consumption and the stagnation of fishing extraction capacity. But at this time, I want to highlight the economic importance of this activity, which generates economic wealth and creates jobs.
It is important to have health guarantees, sustainability is important, and protecting the marine environment is important.
The image of aquaculture needs to be enhanced, and the scientific and research sector must also be strengthened.
Aquaculture is an opportunity, as Mr. Martín Fragueiro has stated, within the CFP, as the Commissioner mentioned.

It is necessary to provide it with a coherent coordinating framework, and the opportunity to regularize itself, because aquaculture can ensure self-sufficiency, sustainability, and economic resources, and I believe it is important for Europe.
Thank you, Mr. President. In my view, this excellent report outlines the guiding principles that should inform the new transport white paper, shaping European transport policy for the next ten years.

This report has several notable milestones. The need for a financial fund as an indispensable instrument. The challenge of the growing demand for freight transport. The search for multimodal solutions that

provide security for users and goods. The pressing need for sufficient and safe rest areas in road transport. The accurate diagnosis, in my opinion, that there should not be mere competition between the different

modes, but rather to complement each other in the pursuit of efficiency criteria. The rapporteur's brave and, in my view, fair statement that rail or maritime transport is not always more environmentally friendly than road transport.
In essence, the concept of an efficient community is a forward-thinking notion that, in my view, should undoubtedly be supported with the utmost rigor.
yours, Mr. President, a mistake in the approach.
Did you think you would actually preside over Europe and influence the gears that drive the complex European machinery?
He even came to believe, as those close to you proclaimed, that the world would experience a stellar moment under his presidency.
None of this has come to pass.
Let's get some clarifications.

During these six months of the Spanish presidency, I would like to distinguish between, on the one hand, the political direction and, on the other, the work of the officials who have been laboring in the engine rooms.
It is the first one that has failed, and this is due to the absence of adequate momentum from the presidency of the government, which has been more of a pendulum swing.
However, I would like to emphasize the efforts of the officials, their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And it is, Mr. President, that Spain has magnificent professional civil servants, and what is to be regretted is that they are overly constrained in their daily reality.
Having said this, it is necessary to acknowledge that some commendable initiatives have been undertaken in these six months.
Among them, I am pleased to highlight the organ donation and transplantation plan, as well as the approach taken towards patient rights in cross-border healthcare.
The agreements on the new 2020 strategy, and especially those concerning the European External Action Service, have been left hanging in the air. Both are still far too fragile.
Regrettable has been what occurred with the European Protection Order for Victims of Gender-Based Violence, and the same grim outcome has been offered by the
basic community patent essential for the life of thousands of businesses and partly blocked by the linguistic problems encouraged by Spanish legislation.

But it is all the major political actions that have ended in spectacular failure. From the Mediterranean summit to that of the European Union with the United States, the latter being one for which his own government was responsible for creating excessive expectations.
However, we must acknowledge that the inability to advance their policy toward Cuba has been highly beneficial for the Cuban people.
Lastly, the progress made in the pursuit of improved European economic governance cannot in any way be attributed to its presidency, which has been conspicuously absent on the most crucial matters.
Farewell, then, to the Spanish presidency.

A positive conclusion I wish to draw from this experience. My fantasy, as a convinced Europeanist, is stirred by the thought that it could signal the end of rotating presidencies, as they have been conceived until now.
This would be good news, for as long as Europe does not strengthen its common institutions, solidly uniting its fragments, it will continue to risk sinking into the vacant spaces of irrelevance.
Mr. President, believe me, Mr. Zapatero, I would have liked to deliver a different speech today.
Your Honor set a semester brimming with ambition and established such a high standard in his aspirations that when compared to what was actually achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The fact is that your lordship has not been able to overcome a complex situation that required leadership and credibility.
Your Honor has reminded us at times that the European Union is a club with rules, and I agree.
But it was your lordship that was supposed to enforce the observance of those rules.
The reality is that it was the Government of Spain to whom they imperatively demanded the fulfillment of its obligations.
In this picture, positive achievements, which have not been lacking, have been overshadowed.
Your Honor has had time to relate them, I have not.
Democracy, your honor, is a regime of public opinion.
And that is what it seems to be. Obama's disdain, the cancellation of the Mediterranean summit, and the announced European Union-United States alliance represent significant failures.
The rush to close improvised agreements at any cost has not enhanced the image of Spanish management. The way in which some respectable objective has been achieved has been described as shoddy.
Spain is a great nation and will continue to be so despite poor management during this time.
Our diplomats and officials have maintained their composure, and thanks to them, Spain's prestige will endure.
The truth is that the value judgment that will be made of this presidency will weigh more on the situation of Spain than on what I have done or not done here.
It is hardly possible for someone who has placed their country in a state of uncertainty and unrest to lead a company so challenging.
This is the best-case scenario. This presidency has sadly proven to be irrelevant.
Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming months we will be fully engaged in the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope the Belgian presidency achieves what the Spanish presidency has not, that is, to steer the discussions in such a way that member states commit to maintaining a coherent policy in the future.

truly robust common agricultural policy, with a sufficient budget to meet the needs of all 27 Member States, both new and old. And let us not find ourselves in the same situation as in 2005, when there was a lack of funds and modulation had to be invented.

In the upcoming reform of the CAP, we are staking the viability of a sector that not only provides intangible goods and services, such as environmental care, but also should ensure the supply of food to European citizens.

We have already witnessed painful situations of scarcity in the past, so it is necessary for the European Parliament to provide security and supply based on community production, as the main objective of the upcoming reform, without overlooking other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues, I agree with Commissioner Cholos that this report is very necessary and comes at a good time, because the abuses committed by large-scale distribution have been demonstrated, severely disrupting the different links in the food chain.

The Bové report, which at times may go too far in its attempt to be overly interventionist, must be recognized from the perspective of a social market economy, as advocated by the European People's Party. It addresses the legitimate demands of European producers.

Furthermore, it brings transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always beneficial, and provides many more opportunities and means of defense for the weakest sectors in that chain. It also, of course, supports European consumers in gaining a better understanding of the food chain.

The European food industry could perhaps have been taken into account more within this report, and that would have been very positive. However, this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, which was greatly needed.
Measures are also included to bring equity to these links in the chain, as called for by the Environment Committee. There is also a call to combat abusive and unfair practices of large distributors.
And it is high time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to categorically prohibit them.
It is important, moreover, to adopt measures to prevent unfair practices through private labels that undermine competition and infringe intellectual property law.

For all these reasons, we must support the BOVE report and all the colleagues from the various parliamentary committees—INCO, Transport, and Agriculture—who have worked tirelessly to ensure that this report finally sees the light of day and assists European producers in moving forward.
The alarm bell rings and it's true.
And frustration is also heard, as can be heard in the interventions of this Plenary, for not having achieved the millennium goals.
And the truth is that what is at stake is immense.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if, one day, the big fish decides not to keep eating the small one, we would all have to pay for it with our health and well-being as the generational price.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change, and has been for some time in pioneering and conservation measures.

However, as the unmet objectives demonstrate, it appears that there was a lack of will, not only in terms of implementation and coordination, which have also been mentioned here, but also in terms of expansion, to go beyond our strictly delimited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be confined to a ghetto-like area, as it sometimes seems to be treated, with only an occasional glance in its direction.
Biodiversity is alive and knows no borders. It spans the entire Earth with a domino effect, where if one piece falls, all the others fall as well.

And I draw attention to the need for a more global and community-oriented will, especially regarding the soil, because subsidiarity as the sole method for soil or forest management can be one of the new formidable enemies of biodiversity.

That is why I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the possible vote that will be taken, and I ask you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on soils would contribute to the conservation of the entire territory.

so varied, so diverse for good and for ill, and so lacking in political will on the part of the States, and so in need of ever more European union, in the fullest sense of the word and all that it entails, more union also for the land.

Thank you, Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner. First of all, I would like to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Ms. Macaban, not only in terms of content but also in terms of form, as she has done it in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.
Also, thank the experts from the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this agreement.

The objective of this pharmacovigilance system of the European Union is to enhance the surveillance, transparency, and communication of the safety of medicines after they have been placed on the market, particularly with regard to their risk profiles and the adverse reactions they may cause.

It is important to highlight the establishment of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will evaluate and provide recommendations to the European Medicines Agency on safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.

It is very important to reach a solution for the notification to pharmacovigilance of suspected adverse reactions, both by the Member States and by the marketing authorization holders of the medicines.

...Eudra Vigilance will be the sole source of information... ...but simultaneously, the competent authority... ...of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected to have occurred will be informed... ...and this is very important...
It is also important to highlight the opportunity available to consumers to report any adverse reactions, and in this regard, the creation and management by the agency of an environmental portal.
A European portal on drug safety, which in turn links to the portals of each member state, will help improve citizens' knowledge about the safety of the medicines they consume.

And lastly, we cannot forget that, since pharmacovigilance plays a crucial role in safeguarding public health, the adoption of the directive and the subsequent implementation of the regulations are of utmost importance.
This directive and regulation will contribute significantly to this by improving not only current procedures but also the coordination of actions among the different Member States.
Thank you, Mr. President.

Recognition of the sanctioning authority by providers, as well as the alternative resolution excluding mass exchanges as a potential infringement, make it impossible to vote in favor of either of the two competing reports.
The Galó report has generated great interest and could have been timely, but the core of the debate is too entrenched around the discussion for or against the French law known as ASEC.
of internet disconnection for infringers, without there having been a genuine European debate that takes into account the reality of other advances in national legislations.

I hope we can reach a common position within the Socialist group and a majority in the European Parliament during the debates and amendments on the Commission's proposed directive, which will soon be submitted to Parliament, as announced by Commissioner Barnier.

On that occasion, we will aim to achieve a more balanced position than we have today, one that takes into account both the rights of Internet users and the indispensable respect for intellectual property.
I congratulate those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the officials and Members of this Parliament.
A financial crisis of enormous proportions had to occur for Europe to wake up.
However, an opportunity has been partly missed to strengthen Europe's common institutions. Because, on the one hand, these new supervisory authorities have a scope of competence
facing similar authorities from member states, and it is also a pity that no progress has been made towards a similar integration to that which occurred with the system of central banks.
We have made progress, but it is necessary to continue climbing the mountain.

As a member of the Human Rights Committee, as a Spanish and European citizen, and as a victim of terrorism since the terrorist organization ETA assassinated my brother and his wife in Seville, I address this Parliament to denounce the Government of Venezuela and its president for allowing ETA terrorists to disappear.

...are trained in Venezuelan dreams......under the command of alleged terrorist Cubilla......who works for the government of Hugo Chávez......despite the fact that there is......an international arrest warrant against him......which constitutes a serious violation......of the fundamental right to security......of any European citizen...
I demand that the Spanish Government take decisive action in response to this grave humiliation of the Spanish people as a whole.

The shoemaker cannot continue to remain silent while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our Civil Guard officers torturers, when they have been and will continue to be an example of bravery in the fight against ETA.
nor can it turn a blind eye to this growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as Judge Eloy Velasco already denounced.
A shoemaker cannot shake the hand of a leader like Chávez, who is turning Venezuela into a haven for terrorists.

The president of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this issue and should provide a response, one that is deserved and one that any ordinary citizen would give if given the opportunity.
On February 14, 2008, as a Valentine's Day gift, the Conference of Presidents decided that intergroups would only meet on Thursdays.
Since then, we have attempted to resolve this issue.
We have not succeeded.
Intergroups today, Mr. President, have to meet on a date that is not appropriate...
They never have rooms and they never have interpretation.

Today, I speak not only as President of the Poverty and Human Rights Intergroup, but also with the mandate of the majority of the intergroups in this House, and thus, on behalf of the members of this House who are part of those intergroups.
And I solemnly request that the Conference of Presidents reconsider and revoke the decision of February 14, 2008, and return to the previous situation of intergroup freedom.
And if you do not, I also kindly state that we will bring the matter to the plenary of this House, and it will decide who is sovereign in this House, which is this Parliament.
Mr. President, the International Day against Trafficking in Persons for Social Exploitation revealed some data that should prompt us to act decisively.
Over 90% of prostitution in Europe stems from blackmail and extortion.

And in light of these data, we should ask ourselves whether we are doing everything necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also protected by the Fundamental Charter that we adopted with the Treaty of Lisbon.
Because we are not talking about the oldest profession in the world, but about the only form of slavery that we have not managed to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries like Spain are making significant efforts in this regard, prosecuting traffickers, raising awareness among citizens, and promoting rehabilitation programs for female victims.
But it is not enough.
Europe must be a single space for action and commitment.

The next directive on treatment is an opportunity to act on demand through pedagogy and to make access facilities more difficult, for example, in the offer to advertise in all types of media. In addition to increasing bilateral cooperation with third states to combat this scourge from its source.
...we have an opportunity...
I call on this Parliament to continue to be at the forefront of citizens' rights.
Thank you, Madam President. We all agree that the external service represents a historic opportunity for European construction.

But to achieve this, it is necessary to act with a broad perspective, because this is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are transferred or withheld in the short term, nor for wars between the different European institutions.

What is now required, on the contrary, is to have a comprehensive vision of what the European Union should be in the world. In other words, to do precisely the opposite of what has been done in the past.

Mr. President, the regulation we are debating today is of vital importance for the future of a sector, that of cutlery and related industries, which in my region, the land of Don Quixote, specifically in Albacete, represents not only the survival of over 8,000 jobs but also an element of identity and a commitment to the future of craftsmanship as a job-generating source.
The Meidín branding on knives has long been championed by social groups such as Aprecu and fought for by the Government of Castilla-La Mancha with the unanimous support of its regional Parliament.
A seal of origin that is not interventionism is a commitment to the transparency of trade rules and the fight against unfair competition.

is to enhance consumers' decision-making ability when choosing a product, so that they consider not only the final price, but also the quality brand, place of origin, or social conditions under which it is produced.

And, above all, it will open a new horizon of optimism for many people who are going through difficult times, but who are looking to us today, believing that we have not been indifferent in our commitment to fairer trade. Yes, but also in adding value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best working conditions of European workers.
Therefore, I thank the opponent and Mr. Menéndez del Valle for their political support and social awareness on this important issue for my homeland.
Thank you, Mr. President. Let me attempt to bring a bit of calm to this lively debate.
It is regrettable that, alongside the European Union, certain countries and constituent states continue to be present in this G20 forum.
Despite this anomaly, which undoubtedly weakens Europe's image in the world, it would be desirable for there to be at least a common global position in that world forum.
And what, in my opinion, would that common position be?

In my humble opinion, I believe that, firstly, we cannot delay the adoption of a global agreement to address the consequences of the crisis, and not just a financial agreement. Secondly, Europe must maintain the euro as a reference currency or, if you prefer, as an anchor for the future.

prevent the turbulences in the markets from dragging us down and forcing us to repeat the mistakes made throughout the twentieth century. Thirdly, the euro must serve as a herald of what Europe should represent in the world of democratic values and human freedoms.
publics
In summary, it is important to understand that in the globalized world, in this global game, those who only play the national cards lose.
Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe we should congratulate the rapporteur, Ms. Meisner.
There were differing, even conflicting, positions, and she obtained compromise solutions that allow us all to be together on an important matter.

Ladies and Gentlemen, the Transport Committee has resolved that all bars should be afforded similar protection, invoking the argument that failure to do so would result in an unfair competitive situation.

We accept the majority's position in favor of a legal situation with uniform rules for the entire Union, but I will not spare your Lordships the clear statement that it also entails a certain lack of equity.
It is evident that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea, and the English Channel are more polluted areas, and that sulfur limit value controls will need to be more stringent in their case.
The measures relating to ports should be positively valued in terms of their impact on reducing transport times and handling costs.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that we have an outstanding issue at this point.
Without a decisive liberalization of ports, they will not be able to expand the central role they must play in the context of intermodal transport.
Welcome, ladies and gentlemen, is also the impetus for a strategy aimed at modifying the specific impacts of climate change on the city.
I believe this is a positive report that should be voted on.
But we cannot forget that it occurs in the context of a serious disaster, which is that of the Gulf of Mexico.

In this regard, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework for the review of the regulation of the European Maritime Safety Agency strengthens the role the Agency should play in preventive inspections and subsequent oil spill cleanup tasks.
My personal opinion, Madam Commissioner, is that yes, these tasks should be reinforced with the appropriate mandate for that purpose.

Thank you, President. The integrated maritime policy is a cross-cutting, regional, and sectoral policy, which must include fisheries policy and agriculture, and it should not be subordinated to other policies.
We must all address environmental and economic issues, both for society at large and the fishing sector. New technologies, fishing gear, species development, a maritime economy plan.

for greater employment, quality supplies, international relations that prevent piracy, and to promote the governance of our barrier-free seas, avoiding sustainability issues as seen in the case of Iceland.
This would be working towards an integrated maritime policy. This would be working for the environment and sustainability.
Recently, the Church of Our Lady of Succour in Baghdad was assaulted, and 58 people were killed, most of them women and children, solely because they were Christian.
Al-Qaeda has proudly claimed responsibility for the feat.
This is not an isolated incident, but the culmination of persecutions and attacks on Christians in countries with a majority Muslim population.
Expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo. How long will the complicit silence of Western democracies continue?
Fortunately, President Buseca has made an institutional statement.
The condemnation statement by High Representative Ashton was limited to condemning a terrorist act.
Why is the mobile device not cited? The condition of being Christian is the unequivocal cause of the massacre.
I hear nothing from Mr. Zapatero. I have not heard anything from President Erdogan.
What is the purpose of the Alliance of Civilizations?
I feel shame for our provincialism and our cowardice.

Inevitably, my memory turns to the lamented and misunderstood Oriana Fallaci, who foretold the advent of Eurabia and was nearly stoned for having the courage to denounce what is happening in complex Europe.
Thank you also to the Commissioner. I share the wish of this House.
I want the proposals from the Europeans to receive the support they deserve in Cancún.
In relation to this debate, it is important to underscore the role of cities in environmental conservation.

There is a pact among more than a thousand mayors of the European Union that demonstrates a recognition of the problem on the part of these authorities, whose action proves decisive if we are to achieve success.
No amount of grand rhetoric will avail us if we do not have the collaboration of the mayors of the cities.
For this, it is very important to publicize emissions, as cities produce almost 80% of greenhouse gases.
Today, there is no such disclosure, nor, worse still, a common standard for measuring these emissions.
There is a non-profit organization called the CO2 Disclosure Project that already hosts information from thousands of companies and which I believe could also be used by municipalities.
Without their participation, without the involvement of these municipalities and mayors, environmental action amounts to hot air, the very hot air we are seeking to escape.

Thank you, President. Some have argued that the condemnation of Morocco is too lenient given the extent of the human rights repression in the Sahara, where Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country without any sovereignty or legal title.
But the important message is that all of Europe and this Parliament will no longer tolerate your violence.
Yesterday, I spoke about the Hague Tribunal in this very Parliament.

The international community, which sadly failed to prevent genocide in Rwanda, Yugoslavia, and Darfur, I hope will nevertheless prevent it in Western Sahara and we will not have to see it before another court, also in The Hague as mentioned, but this time for war crimes.
President, commissioner, the directive adopted in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework that has been governing toy safety.
It is a significant step in the right direction as it points us towards the path to follow, but it is not enough.
We must always remain vigilant and attentive to ensure that the toys being marketed do not jeopardize the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.

We must review and improve surveillance mechanisms to detect hazardous toys, whether due to toxic substances, ECMR (estimated chronic daily intake), fragrances, and other dangerous substances such as HPA (High Production Volume) compounds.
It is necessary for the guidelines to be clearer regarding the warning about the minimum age and the dangers resulting from improper use.
The recommended age for toys should be based on studies of children's behavior.
We need to be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advancements backed by robust studies, and be more rigorous in market surveillance and the importation of toys.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation among member states, and to have the joint work of customs authorities to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are preparing to do their Christmas shopping, and we must assure them that the products they purchase meet all safety requirements.
that in this debate we have made it clear that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
Different political groups have shown their support for this directive, which provides greater protection for victims.
Therefore, I ask myself, what obstacle exists in approving this instrument?
I repeat, what are the fears that something as necessary and straightforward as protecting victims equally across Europe is finally becoming a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will overwhelmingly approve this report, I address the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
overcome the legal obstacles in our negotiations. And I applaud the Commission for recognizing our work, as we recognize the work it will do in the future.

Therefore, we should not exclude ourselves but rather support each other by approving this more concrete instrument today. Tomorrow, we will have the broader package of measures to assist victims, which the commission will present, and I undertake to collaborate on this.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today, and help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let us help everyone, I repeat, whether they are men, women, or children.
Let us help those who look to us today for a better life, a life that restores their freedom, their security, and above all, their dignity.

Mr. President, the European People's Party group will be voting enthusiastically for this report, and my congratulations go firstly to the rapporteurs, the committee, and the council for this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, in the 1980s the term democratic deficit.
By this, we meant that in the European Union, decisions were made solely by the Council of Ministers upon proposals from the Commission, and this Parliament was merely consulted.
The battle of this Parliament since the 1980s, through the Maastricht Treaty, the Amsterdam Treaty, the Nice Treaty, the Constitutional Treaty, and the Lisbon Treaty, has been...

to bridge that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, and with the involvement of national parliaments, we have achieved that goal.
And we round off today with this citizen legislative initiative, which was due in the Convention's work to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament.

And I would like to mention here the names of Jürgen Mayer, our German Social Democratic colleague, and Anand Lamassur, who were the ones who brought this initiative to the plenary of the convention and ensured its approval.
Therefore, I believe we have come full circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have brought to the table, laid bare, the death certificate of the concept of democratic deficit.
It is now our turn, ladies and gentlemen, to act responsibly. And today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the Union's budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us: a responsible Parliament and a co-decision-making Parliament.
I believe this is a good day for Europe, ladies and gentlemen.
In January 2012, 400 Spanish egg producers, approximately 30% of the total in my country, could disappear. This would result in a loss of 300,000 tons of egg production.

And the European Union could stop producing those 80 million eggs, those 2 million tons, and we would only achieve having them covered by imports from third countries, whose animal welfare standards are far inferior to those of the European Union, if we do not act with great intelligence.
This directive from the year 99, which mandates an increase in the space of hen cages, requires us to act with intelligence and a pragmatic vision, because if not...

We will only succeed in weakening European production and providing additional opportunities, trade opportunities, to third countries where the space per bird is infinitely worse than what we currently have in the European Union.

This is a directive that demands tremendous effort from European producers. Just in Spain, we can see that the cost increases to around 600 million euros. However, we must not forget, in addition, that it has an economic impact that extends to the ovoproduct industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore request the support of your lordships for the amendment of the Popular Group to the second paragraph, where it is requested to seek a solution, at least for responsible holdings, of responsible farmers, who are proceeding with the transformation of their holdings and who, by January 2012, will almost have finished.

There is a need to support them in transforming these facilities and to give them time to complete this process, thereby avoiding irreparable harm to farms and preventing a sudden shortage situation in the community market, which would consequently drive up consumer prices.
It is a matter of adhering to the directive, of giving the egg and ovoproduct industry a chance, while also respecting the right to animal welfare and the consumers' right to a reasonable price.

Mr. President, I believe it is only fair to thank the rapporteurs, especially Ms. Grostet and Ms. Dagmar Romberen from my own group, for the work they have done to unblock this file and make it useful, as this work has made it possible to include the right to public health as a legal basis.

and to provide a new direction that allows us to lay the foundations to guarantee citizens the safety and quality they choose at each moment. Especially since it also clearly regulates the role of the States, both those of origin who have to make the payment and those where the treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not be satisfied with this alone, but rather that this must be the beginning of a much greater advancement that, as Mrs. Romberen said, makes this directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all states will make it unnecessary for each citizen to travel to every country.

And in this struggle, we must obtain a standard that guarantees the rights of citizens in relation to the care they should receive, benefits, similarity, and security, more than merely the right they already have to mobility between states.
Equality is what will bring union, and if not, we will be taking very small steps.

Madam President, the Spanish Socialist delegation has voted in favor, like the rest of our group, but I would not feel comfortable leaving without making clear my concern that certain elements have been included in this directive...
the issue of organ transplants, which goes against the stance of the Environment Committee due to the Council's persistent insistence on including transplants in this directive.

I hope that this inclusion does not diminish the effectiveness of the good legislation we approved in this very Plenary, both with the Transplant Directive and the Action Plan, very recently and with almost unanimous support.

And I caution that we will be vigilant to ensure that this inclusion does not undermine the excellent work done by organizations as successful as the Spanish National Transplant Organization, and certainly not the ambition to save 20,000 lives that we had in both the Transplant Directive and the Action Plan, which, I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I make it clear and state that we will remain vigilant in ensuring compliance with this directive in that regard.
Mr. President, today is also European Sexual Health Day.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the data is concerning. The World Health Organization estimates that over 300 million people are involuntarily infected with a sexually transmitted disease each year.

In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, the increase in the number of unwanted pregnancies among teenagers due to an excessive deficit of education and information among our youth is concerning.

Indeed, as the Commission points out, there are diverse and significant inequalities in access to sexual health services across Europe, varying from country to country and, within each country, depending on the income level of citizens.
To combat all of this, a European strategy is necessary.

Only in five member states are there plans in this regard, but in all of them, it has been possible to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies, infections of sexually transmitted diseases, and also the number of abortions.
A common strategy that prioritizes prevention through education, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and improves accessibility to contraceptive methods.
A cross-cutting and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to ensure every citizen's right to sexual health under the highest conditions of safety and hygiene.
In times of intense social tensions, it is nothing short of encouraging to witness the significant social dialogue agreement in Spain between the government, trade unions, and employer associations.
This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where such significant milestones have not been achieved in a long time.

Also of great note are the arguments of Cándido Méndez, one of the main protagonists of that Spanish pact, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February 8.
Candido then insisted on the need to extend coordination to a European scale and on the necessity of having the voice and initiatives of trade unions in our Europe.
It must be so...

Thank you, President. Setting aside the differences in matters of terrorism and immigration, I have observed that the European Union, unfortunately, acts primarily in response to emergency situations, such as a serious assassination.
an attack or a massive landing of immigrants as is currently happening in Lampedusa, where the exodus of Tunisian citizens to the Italian coast could result in a chronicle of a death foretold.

The journey of hope can end in a cursed voyage, and it will weigh on our consciences, on those of all of us who witness these continuous, uncontrolled flows and do not say 'enough' with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we will put our hands to our heads, but the next day we will forget.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth: that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, that the common immigration policy will remain a dream, as long as European countries do not commit to providing sufficient economic resources to make it effective.
Talking costs nothing, but action is required.
act. Do you truly believe that Frontex, as it stands, can ensure security at European borders?
I believe not.

And let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt, and other Maghreb countries do not decide en masse to seek a better future in Europe, but rather do so in their own countries, because that is what they have fought for, and we must contribute to helping them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth when discussing a common European migration policy, which is today more necessary than ever.

Madam President, as has already been stated, the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and should remain the public system, because it is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is noteworthy that in OECD countries, the highest levels of income equality among citizens are found in pension systems, or that due to the crisis, private pensions lost a staggering 20% of their value in 2008 alone, and to this day, they remain far from the required solvency levels.

All this demonstrates that at a time of inevitable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be approached in a comprehensive manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies on natality or work-life balance.

some equally ambitious policies on access to and retention in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that also guarantee, from a demographic standpoint, the sustainability of our pensions.
Finally, I regret that the text does not set limits on the abuse of company scholarship programs, as, generally speaking, these are exempt from all kinds of social contributions.

In my opinion, this is indispensable for an entire new generation of workers who, while being demanded more to secure a decent pension, would also need to suffer less to gain access to decent employment.

President, Commissioner, we are at a crucial juncture in shaping the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects but also on the territorial dimension.
Territorial cohesion aims for harmonious development among territories to enable their citizens to make the most of their unique territorial characteristics.
But to achieve this goal, it is also necessary to make progress in the area of cooperation between the regions of the Union that face the same challenges and issues.

This is the goal pursued by the European Union's Atlantic Region Strategy. A common perspective to tackle the shared challenges faced by the region's states. Among others, marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with Strategy 2020 and the European Union's policies for the post-2013 period, particularly with regional policy and maritime policy.
However, ladies and gentlemen, above all, it is necessary for this strategy to be based on renewed multi-level governance, founded on closer involvement of public authorities.
regional and local levels, Member States, the European Union, and stakeholders from the private sector and civil society organizations, including interregional organizations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, as we celebrate International Women's Day, remembering those who, 100 years ago, fought for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage.
We have come a long way in these 100 years, but there is much left to do and true equality is still a dream, while discrimination against women is a real fact.

I believe that each one of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women. Because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, whose dignity is violated, and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this International Women's Day, to express my support and hope for all the women who, in the revolution in North Africa, are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman cannot be worth half of a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere in the world.
Therefore, we are of equal value and deserve the same.
And I will continue fighting to achieve it. And as long as that equality does not exist, International Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although there are many who do not want to see it, it is a reality that there are women who earn half as much as men, that domestic violence predominantly affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all these facts in this Parliament, and I certainly promise to keep working.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my agreement with the views of the members who have spoken this morning and who insist on respect for the Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest positive vote will depend on the European Council being willing to acknowledge the role of the aforementioned institutions.
because the new mechanism we are discussing should be an important component of the economic governance led by a European Union.
able to ensure coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise, and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

In other words, it must be avoided at all costs that this effort in which we are embarked ends up in the intergovernmental track, which is a dead end or the track of the predominance of a few states, because all of this would frustrate the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of those that reinforce and balance this delicate structure.
There are essential points that need to be improved, so we must send the report back to the committee.
It is not me who concludes the parliamentary iteration of this report.
The initial proposal was poor.
This is what consumer associations were telling us at both the national and European levels.
And in particular, I value the work of the Consumers' Union of Asturias and its president, the indefatigable Dacia Alonso.
We have succeeded in rejecting the general principle of maximum harmonization of the former Article 4.

It must be stated clearly that achieving maximum harmonization by establishing the same level of protection in all member states would result in a reduction of consumer protection for many, as certain countries have a stronger tradition and higher standards in safeguarding consumer rights.

I would like to emphasize in any case that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, thereby allowing each Member State to increase the number of clauses it considers unacceptable and invalid in consumer contracts.

reverse the burden of proof in individual clauses. Thus, it is the merchants who must demonstrate that the clauses that deviate from the generally established norms have been individually negotiated. Contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and understandable manner.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonization regarding abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer survey reveals that 79% of traders believe full harmonization in this area will have little or no impact on their overseas operations.
Thank you, Mr. President. Madam Commissioner, allow me first of all to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Swab, and Ms. Gerhard on the excellent work done.
and a general reflection.
It is not about increasing protectionism, but rather about not curtailing already existing rights in some of the Member States.
Because if we aim to and strive to establish an authentic internal market for relations between businesses and consumers, we must set up
establish a balance in parallel between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of business competitiveness.
This balance involves agreeing on a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that enhance consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community standard to result in the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I am pleased that negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to insist that the rights already established so far should not be curtailed.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis could be an energy crisis, and moreover, we are either not doing the necessary homework to prevent it or we are not doing it at the necessary speed to avert it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature is calling on all of us to make a small gesture in the name of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the lights for an hour, and many public administrations will join them.
But it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are far away, or on insecure energy sources.
We must assist states in constructing a new energy model where renewable energies are at the core of the new framework.
We must also support the promotion of new consumption patterns, because, without a doubt, renewables and efficiency are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I would like to appeal to all countries of the Union to join this call, to the willingness of five of its states, including Spain, to increase CO2 emission reductions to 30%, because by doing so, we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being at the forefront of freedom and rights, is also a leader in its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Thank you very much. Most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, it has been to denounce violence against women, and I am here again to combat it.

I must say that not only am I not tired of it, but I deem it essential to continue speaking publicly about this human rights violation, as there is no cause that can be defended without a platform, and this Parliament is the most suitable one.

speaker that I have at my disposal to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us, legislators, to compel states to punish aggressors according to the severity of the crime and also to assist the victims.

When it is estimated that a quarter of European women have suffered gender-based violence at least once in their lives, and that children are equally affected, I believe it is impossible not to call for greater commitment, as recognized by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe it is necessary to keep insisting time and again, to protect victims as we already did in the European Protection Order for Victims, of which I was the rapporteur, and which I hope will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has enjoyed broad consensus and support from the outset, demonstrating that when it comes to tackling domestic violence affecting all members of the household,
family, children, elderly people, women and men, should not be a reason for political opportunism, as we all take pride in making progress towards solving this social scourge.

The first thing is to not remain silent, and the second is to get to work, since although we have been talking about gender-based violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

Something we are doing must be wrong, and therefore it is time to abandon demagoguery and move from words to actions, providing more real help and the necessary attention so that women can live with dignity and security.
safety. Let all the victims know that I will always be here to continue lending them my voice until together we manage to defeat this.
a terrible enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough already, and I ask all of you to say it with me too.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Thank you very much, Commissioner. I agree with you that we must listen to citizens and regain trust in the European project.
Therefore, today could be a great day for Europe and European social construction.

because with the approval of these reports, we not only move forward towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we also respond to the demands of citizens who call for progress towards a stronger Europe and the reinforcement of social rights.
Europe must respond to new global challenges and transform the European economy into a highly competitive social market economy, creating sustainable growth with more and better jobs.

But this objective must be based on the inclusion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market. It should place citizens at the center of our attention and priority, and strengthen their social rights.
Lastly, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, by extension, to our public health.

A disease against which we were fighting through the use of activated vaccines, which entails the creation of restricted zones for animal movement, as the use of these vaccines can lead to unwanted virus circulation in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of the vaccine, the practice of vaccination, was limited to those areas where infected animals had previously been found, creating a double disadvantage for livestock farmers. On one hand, the disease, and on the other, the restrictions.

But all these problems seem to be preventable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to avoiding the disruptions that can be caused in the domestic livestock market, allows for the development of new and broader strategies, which is truly the most important aspect of prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all these reasons, it is of vital importance for this sector that we amend the directive to allow its use, and moreover, that we do so as soon as possible.

Ladies and Gentlemen, compliance with what our treaties stipulate, especially regarding the correspondence tables, cannot be an excuse for this regulation not to enter into force before the summer, because with our delay, with your delay, we would only be harming livestock farmers.

Firstly, I would like to thank the Petitions Committee for the work it has done following the complaint lodged by FEPEX, the Spanish Organization of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters, on the basis of the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the Union's Anti-Fraud Agency.

I believe the conclusions of that report are crystal clear and more than justify the European Commission having already rolled up its sleeves a long time ago to clarify the functioning of the entry price system, at the very least for the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to address potential loopholes that may arise from the entry price regulation in force, but it has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without first resolving the flaws in the current import regime.

Ladies and Gentlemen, it is high time the European Commission took its responsibilities seriously and began investigating where frauds are taking place, eventually requesting the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I believe that under no circumstances should a new agreement with Morocco be ratified without first resolving the details we have outlined.

Our goal is not to halt the signing of international agreements, but rather to ensure that such agreements do not severely harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in those agreements are respected.

As regards the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector merely requests guarantees that the effective implementation of the agreed measures will be carried out. And this is only possible through a reform of the entry price regime currently in force.
Until we have a new entry price system, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will not be able to ratify that agreement which the commission has already closed.

Moreover, if such control is the responsibility of the Member States, it would require a significant financial effort on their part. However, it is also true that we have been advocating for a long time the establishment of a European customs border system, similar to that of the United States, to ensure this effective control.

Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, debating this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because it involves these measures that require the green light from the World Trade Organization, and the commission's preliminary proposal sent to Parliament differs from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe it is necessary to assist Pakistan. We understand that, exceptionally, trade preferences can be granted, as long as they take into account the sensitivities of the
European industry and, in a very special way, the textile sector, which in communities such as the Valencian Community in Spain, are severely suffering the consequences of the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to ascertain that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade are likely unable to be addressed with the urgency these acts require, so we must learn from this for the future.

Will it help Pakistan? Yes, but not with the Commission's original proposals, as they do not take into account the impact of the European industry regarding the application deadlines for sensitive and immune-deficient products.
It would even delay the implementation of these measures as they do not align with the pending text expected to be approved by the WTO. We would be past the deadline.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and believe we will have to vote no.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin my remarks by congratulating all those who have made it possible to reach an agreement.
This is an agreement that we all should applaud as it impacts the daily lives of all citizens. However, with the constructive spirit that defines me, I would like to make a few clarifications.
Firstly, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant, but above all, clear and consistent information.
for consumers regarding the components of textile products. Comprehensive information will be of no use if citizens are then unable to decipher it.
We have achieved a necessary but not sufficient positive step. We should move further and protect those citizens who could become more vulnerable.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to establish a European sizing labeling system based on body measurements, because the first thing we encounter when purchasing a garment is the size.
Therefore, we should be much more ambitious and strive for size harmonization.
Mr. President, three notes on the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and hold great affection for that country, but it is evident that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and imprudence.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European response, we find that the actions taken by the Food Safety Authority and the Commission have been weak, lackluster, and imprecise. They have failed to coordinate or provide effective leadership.
Thirdly, those affected have the right to prompt economic compensation.
But for now, I propose to this Parliament that we organize in Brussels or here in Strasbourg a major exhibition of European gastronomy based precisely on the cucumber.
The lost honor must be reclaimed, a pleasing expression to the German writer Heinrich Bell. The lost honor of cucumber producers must be reclaimed.
Europe is the appropriate setting for this.
First and foremost, we are compelled to express our sincere regret for the 23 victims who have already lost their lives, 22 in Germany and one in Sweden.
And this crisis must be acknowledged as the most compelling evidence that the European Union needs to significantly improve its food alert system and internal coordination.
The involved member states have shown slowness, ineffectiveness, and inaction. Even at this point, after 23 deaths, we still do not know the source of the problem.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during crises such as the current one, resulting in cases of economic ruin and the destruction of jobs that were previously essential.

of unemployment, helplessness, and, of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population. Because while you, from the committee, echoed irresponsible statements by regional authorities,

very misinformed and quite irresponsible German reports, with names and surnames of Spanish farms. Meanwhile, the population remained unknowingly exposed to the bacteria. Believing they were avoiding it, citizens were more exposed than ever to eating something that could harm them.

The European Commission should today, at the Agriculture Council being held in Luxembourg at 2 p.m., propose to the ministers that part of the 2.5 billion euros available as unused remnants of the Common Agricultural Policy be utilized.
those 2.5 billion euros to repair the damage caused as much as possible.

To achieve this, it is necessary to find a legal loophole that allows it. A legal loophole that has already been found in other instances, such as with mad cow disease or dioxins, and which should be found now.
Therefore, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, today in Luxembourg you must rise to the occasion and assume your responsibility.

The German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations made, should undoubtedly support this economic solution from the outset. They should also fund, with their own resources, communication campaigns to restore consumer confidence in horticultural productions. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring the dead back to life, and hopefully, what is being done will prevent more deaths and stop the chain of sick people who are suffering without having done anything to deserve it.

We do not know the causes for certain, but we do know some things that we must call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city-state on another continent.

The arrogance that Mrs. Merkel and her Health Minister display in frequently addressing other nations, if translated into diligence and effectiveness in coordination, would have prevented some of the events that have unfolded.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences for a state that has been the Spanish state and for the most important sector of agriculture. It has brought ruin to thousands of families and small businesses and has discredited the economy for a long time.
I ask you to go to the Council and demand full compensation for those affected, as we cannot demand the lives of the dead.
and that the control systems be reviewed.
and hold Mrs. Merkel accountable.
And that he be asked for less arrogance and more diligence.
and hold it responsible for the damage it has caused.
You cannot ignore that Hamburg is in your state.
you cannot ignore your responsibilities.
You cannot shelter under a decentralized and federal state to cause the harm you have inflicted.

A little more humility, a little better management, and a little less conservatism would have gone a long way in preventing this crisis from spiraling out of control, and Spain and other southern farmers would not have had to endure its painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems, and demand accountability, because in Spain, we are demanding it, Commissioner, from you, the Council, and the German state.
President, we are facing a public health issue, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has stated, and in response, we have sought to blame someone, if not find the cause.

The system has failed. We have 22 deaths, 1,600 affected individuals, and three weeks later, we still do not know the cause. And, appealing to a precautionary principle without scientific basis, I repeat, without scientific basis, Spain is being blamed.
Ladies and gentlemen, the Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
They were not contaminated. I repeat this because some contrary versions have been heard around here.
But to show you the importance of what these words have stirred up, 300,000 jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree with you, Commissioner. It knows no borders. We are asking for accountability for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately. Because Germany has a risk problem at this moment. It has a higher number of affected individuals, but Spain is not at fault.
We demand reparations.
And what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as European consumers feel today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

And it is my responsibility to report to the German authorities that they unjustly and precipitously accused Spanish cucumbers, and specifically the cooperatives in Málaga and Almería, which were model farms and will not recover from these accusations.
Thousands of jobless families wonder why. Why they need an answer and, above all, what their future will be. Not just in Andalusia, but across the entire agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will find a swift solution, I urge the Commission that, when it speaks with the Council today, it demands immediate economic and moral measures for all producers in Andalusia and across Europe who are looking to us with indignation but with hope.
Instead of prioritizing European research and collaboration, German authorities have slandered and harmed cucumber producers and others.
and still no one has resigned in Germany nor offered reparations commensurate with the harm caused,
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
It is intolerable how Mrs. Merkel treats the southern countries in matters of agriculture and finances as well.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
None of that. It lacks credibility. Morally.
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and some other countries share our reluctance to readily accept the so-called Brovilleta proposal.

Coincidence, critique, stems from our status as peripheral countries. Ultimately, we will be the ones paying this unique levy that will be collected by the central European Union states with geographical centrality.
The rationale behind the eurovignette scheme is fraught with significant contradictions, and the supporting argument grows weaker by the day.

Although it is accepted as a starting point that the rationality of internalizing external costs should be considered, in the end, it is not sustainable to argue that in order to alleviate congestion, only heavy vehicles should be penalized while leaving passenger cars exempt, applying the old principle of "the polluter pays" with obvious discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the eurovignette, which was envisioned as a source of infrastructure funding, in the end, only 15% will be allocated to the financing of trans-European networks, and not mandatorily.

but rather as a simple recommendation. In such a way that the incumbent Minister of Finance will allocate the funds collected to the purpose that he or she deems most convenient for the interests of their country within the broad category of infrastructures.
The final result will be nothing less than another blow to road freight transport, which, as of now, is the only mode enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much harsher in the context of an economic crisis.

In that regard, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot afford experiments that could further deteriorate the precarious situation of the European economy by imposing new additional costs.

The food crisis that has been recklessly attributed to Spanish products has resulted in unfair penalties and substantial losses for those already burdened by the eurovignette, freight transporters, and growers of high-quality crops.
These are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, why the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will vote against this draft directive.

You will all understand, dear colleagues, that in assuming the presidency of this session, I wish to express my deep pain and consternation at the passing of Jorge Semprún, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of 87.

In Jorge Semprún, we celebrate the man who was a prisoner in the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the forces of Nazism in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the highly renowned committed writer, a particular collaborator of our program "The European Book of the Year," and we also celebrate the convinced pro-European politician.

I mourn his death, as well as his companion and friend, and I will ask President Budgec to convey to his family and the Government of Spain a message of sincere condolences and solidarity, which I am sure we all share here.
creation of an economic governance space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to the European construction.
We cannot keep turning a blind eye.
It is incoherent to have a single currency while simultaneously lacking the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency requires.
In concrete terms, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, an outright no to competition between national debt issuances, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, and
harmonization of tax policies that ensure citizen equality, combat tax fraud, and help shape a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas, I will be told, are elementary.
But they must be repeated and repeated, because no one listens to them.
And precisely because they do not listen, those dark times of which the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke are upon us.

Thank you very much, President, Commissioner, and esteemed Members. The current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing underscores the necessity of regional policy as the best instrument to reduce development disparities among regions and states.
At the same time, we can recover the positive image of Europe that citizens have lately only associated with harsh austerity measures and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of the solidarity of the European project and social justice, should take into account the following priorities. Firstly, strengthening social cohesion and integrating the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy. Secondly, considering the needs and characteristics that have arisen in the project.

geographical characteristics of regions, especially the most disadvantaged ones. Third, uphold the principle of gradualism in fund allocation to ensure regions do not deviate from the convergence objective, preventing abrupt changes in aid receipt. Fourth, promote an efficient system
equitable.
Lastly, ladies and gentlemen, the authorities are implementing strict budget adjustment policies.
Therefore, the support of the Union is necessary.
I hope the Council takes careful note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I call upon the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastián as European Capital of Culture, as I believe it was selected based on a political criterion, which constitutes discrimination against the other candidate cities.

The president of the court stated that she was chosen to support the peace process. To my knowledge, Spain has a terrorist organization called ETA that has not yet laid down its arms and, two months ago, succeeded in having its political wing, Bildu, govern several municipalities, including San Sebastián.

I do not believe that from Europe we should provide such a powerful platform to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will engage in propaganda to distribute blame among victims and assassins.
killers? Where is the right to freedom and dignity?
of course not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues such as Mayor Oreja and Turgay, Salva, or myself must be escorted.
I believe in the culture of life, not in the culture of the gun. Mr.
Can there be true culture without freedom?
No and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastián becomes a free city for all, it can once again present its candidacy. In the meantime, they should learn the culture of respecting those who think differently.
because tomorrow they may deserve it, but today, with Batasuna and its heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.
Mr. President, firstly, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their fruitful collaboration in drafting this text.
And the same applies to the other fellow members of the committee from this Parliament.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was established. There is no better way to commemorate this event than by discussing Europe's energy infrastructures today.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its policy: a common European internal market, promotion of renewable energies as a means or tool to combat climate change, security of supply, and diversification of its sources.
The Lisbon Treaty devotes a title to energy, Title XXI, where these commitments I have just mentioned are enshrined, along with the promotion of the interconnection of energy networks.
Well then, the objective of the report we have prepared is aimed at correcting energy infrastructures that, according to the European Commission, are outdated and poorly interconnected.
Thus, for example, we see a spectacular increase in electricity generation from wind power in the North Sea and the Baltic, with the immense potential for renewable energy in the south of
Europe and North Africa, with the challenges stemming from large-scale electricity storage, the recharging needs of electric vehicles, among many other urgent issues.
All of this is impossible to address today without devising new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.
In the coming years, therefore, the focus should be on identifying the necessary infrastructure. A. By establishing criteria that allow for the selection of projects of European interest.

b. Eliminating energy islands.
c. Ensuring the implementation of these projects within reasonable timeframes and establishing solutions for the contentious issue of project delays.
authorization procedures and licenses in the Member States. D. Ensuring funding that attracts and drives private investment without prejudice to any necessary public support.

Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central components in the new design incorporated into the report because we have managed to make the report a significant benefit for health.
believing that by reducing energy demand, dependence on imports can be decreased, with the resulting impact on infrastructure needs.
A central concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licenses and authorizations intended to permit the execution of necessary works.
currently become eternalized.
and they are prolonged due to the opposition of the populations to see towers or other types of installations grow in their vicinity.

To resolve this conflict, early information to citizens and the establishment of a warning system have been proposed, to be implemented in the event that a state's authorities fail to respond to a request within a reasonable timeframe.
