Thanks to European aid, food banks have carried out remarkable social work, which should not be paralyzed by the selfishness of some governments.
That work has benefited 13 million people, and thanks to it, with minimal effort, we have managed to make the common agricultural policy a little more significant.

Thank you, Mr. President. The regulation we are debating today is not perfect. It cannot, on its own, resolve the issues of a sector facing structural problems, exacerbated by the economic context we are experiencing with cyclical challenges.
But this regulation, while not perfect, is a decisive step forward in the right direction.

Because if in recent times we have all realized that there is no such thing as a perfect market, it was highly necessary to incorporate into this scenario, where we are also dealing with people's food security, all the regulatory elements and protection measures we could for our producers.

It was highly necessary for us to allow the mandatory nature of contracts with a minimum term and a maximum volume, at least as a defensive tool, because of course our producers do not start from the same negotiating strength vis-à-vis distributors, intermediaries, or re-sellers.
Many things remain to be done.
We will need to improve safety nets and make them more agile and effective.
We must strive to further integrate the sector in the value chain, ensure there is no quota distribution, especially in certain areas, and promote quality policies.

But without a doubt, with our positive vote and with all that remains to be done, today many farmers will be able to see this Parliament defending their labor rights, the most basic of all, which is the right to live with dignity from the income of their labor.
B has aptly pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which increases quotas for certain horticultural products, makes absolutely no sense when the figures of the current agreement are not respected.

It is worth recalling that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters denounced to the Committee of Petitions of this very Parliament the massive influx of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price lower than that established in the agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described place the European farmer in a position of competitive disadvantage.
It should be added that our farmers must adhere to rigorous environmental and social quality standards that our Moroccan partners do not always respect.
To conclude, I will address the issue of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory, and the exploitation of its resources should directly benefit the local population.
Moreover, it constitutes an area over which the UN does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
From the European Union, it is necessary to ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, one that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union regarding quotas and prices. An agreement that combats dumping, does not exploit Moroccan farmers, and above all, upholds the dignity of our European farmers.
This is certainly not the agreement.

In the fourth year, the European Parliament's Petitions Committee requested that the European Commission proceed with a modification of the entry price regime for fruits and vegetables in the Union, a regime that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of productions from third countries, as stated by the Union's own Anti-Fraud Agency, OLAF.
They are mainly Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request has been incorporated into a declaration signed last year by the governments of Spain, France, and Italy.
This fraud is addressed by amending the implementing regulations for the Common Organization of the Agricultural Markets, because aligning the Customs Code does not resolve the issue, Commissioner.

For several years now, I have been advocating, within the Popular Party, the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union is equipped with the necessary instruments to ensure compliance with the agreement in force.
The European Commission argues that it is the member states that must ensure the control of imports.

However, what the Commission does not mention is that the entry price regime is in force, and the one in effect prevents national customs authorities from accurately tracing the prices declared by importers to verify that there are no irregularities.

Modify the implementing rules of the CAP for agricultural products, and we will have resolved part of the problem. Because otherwise, the legal loophole in European regulations prevents national authorities from doing their job properly.

are ceasing to be credible because they do not contribute to resolving the crisis.
Summits where the same agreements are reiterated time and again.

In a telegraphic manner, two ideas. The first, the need to insist that responsible solidarity and the fulfillment of duties are the

Thank you, Madam President. From the European Parliament, I wish to pay tribute today to all women, who, despite having made significant progress since March 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and better working conditions, I believe that gender equality is still a long way off.
Today, women can work without having to ask anyone's permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
We must also remember the women in rural areas, whose labor is overlooked.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

Just this year, there has been an excessive number of women murdered, not counting the serious threats from those who believe they have the right to inflict physical or psychological violence upon them.
It is high time to say enough and to state it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and to the Victims' Directive presented by the Commission, which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
We also have to say, and I would like to remind, that motherhood continues to be an obstacle to women's progression, and I believe this is a trend that should be changed.
I want to send a message of hope, and along with many women, with the help of increasingly more men, we must advance on the path towards equality, opportunities, rights, and also responsibilities.
We have come a long way, but there is much to be done.
I must admit that I do not fully and deeply believe in quotas, but I have to tell you that something needs to be done, and I agree with [the need for action].

I would like to thank many of my colleagues and, of course, Ms. Reding for initiating this debate and moving forward on this path to enable women to reclaim the place they deserve. You can count on my support in this endeavor.

Mr. President. In a context of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting both public health, and in which, as is the case in the community where I live, research centers such as the Príncipe Felipe, specialized in diabetes, are left without funding, this resolution is more timely than ever. It is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes, and we need a Council recommendation that tells states they must increase research, including with stem cells, that they must coordinate their results to optimize them, and that they must establish programs for healthy eating and lifestyle habits.

In short, we must prioritize the health of individuals above all else, and in this case, investigating, coordinating, and implementing national programs overseen by the Commission, while demanding results regarding diabetes, is essential to ensuring the quality of life for Europeans and safeguarding their well-being.

If we dedicate more funds to this, some people will take a little longer to receive their payments. But undoubtedly, those who are currently facing difficulties will have a better quality of life, and as States, as the Council, and as the Commission, we will be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to ensure the health of our citizens.
Mr. President, of the many issues this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions rights market, a market that was born with defects, certainly.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have led to a drastic reduction in the price of carbon. In other words, this price is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is urgent, therefore, to reform the design of a policy on this market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, the entire green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, there is an incentive to increase emissions. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques. And what is worse,
The funding of important projects, such as, for example, those related to energy efficiency or carbon capture plants, will be put at risk.
This is the risk.
It is incumbent upon us, the Commission, and Parliament to conjure it.
Mr. President, few asylum seekers are permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has only just begun this experience.
The cases, however, are of urgent need.
The members of parliament have verified this firsthand during their visit to the Iraqi camps of Palestinian origin in Syria. The news that immediately reached us from Tunisia also confirms this.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between the Parliament and the Council.
Our opponent, the valiant Ruiz Tavares. There are many good parliamentarians, but few with as much tenacity as Ruiz Tavares.
He has fought for the European Parliament to retain the new powers acquired following the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the ongoing work carried out by UNHCR, without which success would not have been possible either.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so desperately needed.
And lastly, many thanks to the Commissioner, and I hope that we can also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of advancing the asylum package in the coming month.

The European social model, of which we are so proud, is not founded solely on our pension, education, or healthcare systems, but also on a way of understanding the balances between employers and employees within companies.

The labor reform approved by the Spanish Government, without dialogue and without consensus, breaks with this social model and distances us from the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, both in terms of job creation and the quality of employment.
A labor reform by itself does not create employment; economic growth does.
What labor law does do is define the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them, and the conditions under which they leave.

And with this reform, where 80% of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be covered by collective bargaining agreements, and where they can be dismissed due to a decrease in company income,

employers will be able to unilaterally modify their schedules. What is clear is that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform that attacks the European social model and prioritizes the competitiveness of the Spanish economy solely in relation to labor conditions, deserves a general strike like the one that must be called tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr. President, Mr. Barroso, let it be known that the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party deems it appropriate and supports the two packages you have presented today, both the labor package and the solidarity aid to Greece, which is closely tied to the coherence of your approach.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times, and events each day remind us that the crisis is far from being resolved.
inevitably, the focus of attention has returned to Spain.
Alarm bells have been unjustifiably set off in the markets, fueled in part by statements that, in my view, Mr. President, were ill-timed.
Some within the context of important elections, where one contender and another cite my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Of course, we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, to divert attention from its own problems, it also concerns itself with us rather clumsily from a political standpoint.
Today here too, some have not been subtle, as the Italians would say, and there has been a lack of political tact.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the situation of the markets does not reflect the strength of Spain.
We are a solvent country with full capacity to honor its debts.
Spanish debt remains below the European Union average, and the Spanish government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed upon with the European Union.
Never, Mr. Esbóvaga, has Mr. Rajoy said that he cannot meet the objectives set by the European Union.
He has said the exact opposite, that he is willing to achieve each and every one of his goals, and he reiterates this every day.

The Government of Spain, in the few months it has been at the helm of the Executive, has adopted and will continue to adopt very ambitious measures to ensure fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for an improvement in competitiveness, job creation, and growth.
The IMF's forecasts, by the way, from yesterday, admit the IMF itself, are prior to the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish government at present.
Other measures we have taken. The General State Budgets for 2012, which in our view will ensure that the deficit target is met this year. The Organic Law on Budgetary Stability.

will introduce a reform of education and healthcare that will involve an adjustment of 10 billion euros. The reform of the financial sector will also undoubtedly contribute to financial institutions having to allocate more than 50 billion euros.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Commission, and what we are asking for is responsibility from everyone.

It is necessary for all of us to be saved together, and Spain with all, without any doubt whatsoever, and criticisms from one side or the other contribute nothing. Either all the countries are capable of coming together and contributing to growth and the new path, or, if not, it will be difficult, naturally, for us to move forward on the terms proposed by the Commission.
Do you want to make Mr. Rajoy, the President of the Government, the protagonist?
That seems fine to me, I wouldn't have any objections.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the inheritance received by the Spanish socialist, communist, and green left, which has left the worst inheritance ever left by any government, when they received the best inheritance ever held by any government.
President, this morning I read in a leading German newspaper the news that Spain and Argentina are involved in a dispute concerning an oil company.
This is precisely the wrong way to approach the matter.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina, and beyond that, with the great European value that is legal certainty and its respect in international commercial relations.
European institutions have excellent legal experts who can find the appropriate instruments in original or derived EU law to neutralize the arbitrariness of Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of Public Law and I offer to collaborate with them.
The credibility of the European Union before its citizens is currently at stake.

Thank you, President. From the Agriculture Committee, we share the ultimate goal of this directive in attempting to shape our energy mix through fiscal policy. However, we are facing a very complex debate.

filled with challenges in economic, social, and environmental terms. What is important is to maintain those balances that allow us to advance further in environmental matters, yes, but also to avoid economic harm and not exacerbate the social crises we are already facing.
It is the case of agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs are increasingly becoming a very significant portion of the fixed costs of our agricultural operations. At a time when, moreover, we are engaged in a debate that combines crises in raw materials markets with a prospect of losing aid and one of the core health and environmental principles that affect their profitability.
...that is why we have fundamentally requested two things...

First, the maintenance of zero-rate deductions in the energy component, now linked to the formulation and implementation of energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the inclusion of
within the sectors considered at risk of carbon leakage, thereby also gaining access to the deductions allowed in the CO2 emissions trading scheme.
In other words, a more environmentally demanding policy, but one that maintains those balances that make our rural environment viable at a time of changes and uncertainties.
We are living through a major controversy that inevitably revolves around the concepts of austerity and growth.
If one hears the noise that is being generated, it would seem that the idea of growth is a bright invention of these times.
Nothing could be further from the truth.
In Europe, the pact known as the Stability and Growth Pact has been in force since 1997.

Therefore, a large part of the policies implemented by European institutions, such as regional cohesion and research policies, are growth-oriented policies that aim to achieve the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and I address the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the greatest chance of being heard, we have no complexes when it comes to engaging in this debate, which we can approach with our heads held high.
This is my minority opinion among the unregistered.

Many thanks, Madam President. Allow me, first of all, to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs, for their assistance with this report, which has significantly strengthened its content.

We all know that the 20th anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which should be the driving force behind economic activity and growth in Europe, key to overcoming the crisis and achieving the objectives of Europe 2020.

In these 20 years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development, within a broad framework of consumer protection, growth, and rights that generate dynamism and security.
and trust. Transparency, a fundamental principle of democracy and good governance, which Commissioner Bernier referred to this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework concerning the protection and training of consumers, and particularly vulnerable consumers.
We are aware that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it challenging to adopt a comprehensive legislative instrument.
This compels us to address the issue of vulnerability through a cross-cutting analysis, taking into account the diverse needs, capabilities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
As an ambitious proposal, it is not sufficient to protect vulnerable consumers because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive, or the options available to them, or their lack of awareness of existing complaint and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

It is for all these reasons that in order to address the shortcomings, that is, the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to strengthen vulnerable consumers and for both the Commission and the Member States to introduce specific measures in their legislations to ensure adequate protection.

that goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where the level of complexity has proven to be higher and where consumers lodge the greatest number of complaints. The financial sector, due to its complexity, implies that potentially any consumer can become vulnerable.

For this reason, the financial services industry is called upon to redouble its efforts to provide understandable, truthful information, abundant in clear explanations and using direct language about the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising

of foods with high fat, salt, and sugar content, and to children and young people, who are the most susceptible to advertising for these foods. The transport sector, which still often faces challenges when vulnerable people travel. The energy and telecommunications sector,

where the lack of transparency creates an added difficulty for consumers in certain cases. For example, in the energy sector, when determining the tariff that best suits their needs. In access to justice, where consumers may face challenges in accessing economic mechanisms.
existing.
Therefore, the Commission and the Member States are called upon, and allow me to draw the attention of the Spanish Minister of Justice, Mr Gallardón, to ensure that rights are not rolled back.
And let us move in the opposite direction to the trends of these difficult times. Employ intelligence and good governance in favor of alternative dispute resolution in consumer matters.
Lastly, it is important to conclude that any one of us can become vulnerable consumers. Many thanks to all the SADOS for their assistance in strengthening this report.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. Truly, I have a sense of despair, almost frustration, which I must share with someone.
will allow me to do it this afternoon with you.

This is the third or fourth debate we have had in this Chamber in recent times on the situation of youth unemployment across Europe. Debate after debate, while youth unemployment rates are skyrocketing in some Member States, we are already nearing 50%.

50% of the working population, while many of them are already running out of any kind of social or unemployment coverage. While all this is happening, while we move from a situation that evolves from concerning to critical,

unsustainable and from the unsustainable to the dramatic. The Commission presents itself once again in this Parliament, in this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, and not as the true government of the Union, which is what it is and moreover what we need.
Commissioner, governing means setting priorities, taking the lead, especially with the aim of achieving some purpose, some goal, and the commission is not doing this.

Governing is not merely about restructuring funds, nor is it about announcing such actions to merely appease public opinion. Instead, it is about implementing an ambitious, long-lasting, and swift strategy to eradicate youth unemployment.

Governing is not resigning oneself to a youth unemployment rate above 20% and being satisfied with a four million euro pilot project, which is ridiculous given the situation, given the scale of the problem we face.

Governing, not yielding to the pressures of the College of Commissioners or other Member States of the Council who strive to convince us that we will only emerge from this financial crisis, from this new wave of recession, by giving up wages, labor rights, or severance pay, that our only future as a generation is one of precariousness.

Because if this were true, moreover, Mr. Commissioner, that we only gain competitiveness precariously and that only by being more precarious will we achieve greater competitiveness, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country, which it is not.
Sweden, Finland, and Denmark are such countries, characterized by exemplary models of relations and also by a model of guaranteed labor rights.
Mr. President, employment is much more than a citizen's right. It is a tool for connection to the system, it is an instrument of social integration and

And therefore, the higher the unemployment rate, the greater the political disaffection. And for this reason, Commissioner, I cannot accept your discussions on matters of competence as a way of doing nothing about youth unemployment.

Because, moreover, Commissioner, when it has been necessary to interpret the treaties loosely to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, you have done so. And when the treaties have had to be reformed to comply with or satisfy the delusions of a particular Member State regarding austerity, we have also done that.
Therefore, what is it that I want to tell you?
There you have, for example, the guarantee of youth employment. It is not necessary to explain it to you.

Fight to increase the budget. Use, if necessary, the European Social Fund as a tool. Design an implementation mechanism that is both funded and solidarity-based, providing the most support to those with the highest unemployment rates. Push for further changes to this policy of social asphyxiation towards countries that are suffering the most. And remember that behind every figure there is a person who is struggling.
So, you will think as I do that the least important thing is not who the competition belongs to, because for the collective of citizens, especially.
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, I would like to thank the Inter-Commission for its work, as well as the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs.

In general, we are faced with a good regulation of the S.G. Plus system, which is necessary, specifically in certain actions related to the enforcement of import rules for textile products that could harm European Union production.
However, we are concerned about the exclusion, starting in 2014, of certain countries from the GSP that are classified as upper-middle-income. Countries, for example, like Latin America.
Because what happens with these middle-income countries that have poorly diversified exports?
diversified? Why not introduce a diversification criterion for exports?
Because this could create a two-speed process. Countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit, distinguishing themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe we should support a transition period, and amendments will be presented with this transition period to adapt to this situation in these countries and provide the possibility of opening negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they can benefit from it.

I already supported Mrs. Anadelcheva's report when I was able to accompany her on the Congo mission along with other parliamentarians. And indeed, I verified that I have seen few peoples with a greater manifest willingness to practice democracy and participate in it.
But for a people to believe in democracy, they also need to believe in their state and their government. And that will not be possible with electoral support or external backing alone.
They also need a demand for corruption to be fought and for the indecent paradox to be broken, which is living in misery in one of the richest countries in the world in terms of resources.

It must be stated and denounced that a portion of the violence they experience is imported or at least encouraged by those unscrupulous multinationals that, from Europe or other continents or states, are willing to engage in corruption, regardless of fueling struggles over these resources to gain the favor of those who govern certain territories.

Therefore, Mr. Astro, even though it may not fall within your immediate purview, I assert that imposing stricter traceability and transparency requirements on European multinationals and other companies from different continents operating in the region would be as beneficial for the development of that population as the electoral and technical assistance we can provide.
Mr. President, I would like to thank the speakers for the valuable work they have presented.

Colleagues, we are now debating Package 2, after having approved Package 6, following the agreement of almost all heads of state and government on two international treaties outside the constitutional order.
After many other European regulations have created more community authorities for banking supervision, stock market supervision, insurance supervision, and for the risks of the economic system.
A proliferation of texts and more texts of reports, of proposals addressing new economic evaluation criteria, new processes, new procedures.
procedures, we must not stop and apply what we already have approved.
In the face of the instability experienced by the European continent, the exact opposite is needed: stability and legal certainty.
We do not need a convoluted series of legal findings.
I don't know, dear colleagues, if I am dreaming.
The situation surrounding the rescue is very concerning.
The Spanish government and the state are assuming private debt as public debt with the new guarantee, but the full truth is not being disclosed to Spanish citizens.
The Spanish government has requested aid that it previously claimed it did not want and is presenting it ridiculously as a triumph, as some colleagues already warned in this debate.
There is no triumph, only failure, with Bankia and the like.

I insist, there is no other correct policy for Europe than that sponsored by the French government, behind which parliamentary ranks must close. For we will not emerge from debt without the harmonious growth of all and the collective whole.

Supervision as claimed in both reports, of course, all the supervision that is necessary, but simultaneous indispensable growth, anti-speculative as well, just as is alluded to in some of the measures of both reports and other reports as well.
Please, also clarity and transparency, balance, as my colleague Sánchez Presedo mentioned earlier.
Madam President, since I entered this Parliament, I have not ceased to denounce female genital mutilation.
That silent and accepted crime suffered by millions of women and girls around the world. 70 million, I repeat, 70 million.

...an unbearable figure......for anyone who takes the time to study......the terrible consequences......of these practices......that hide behind the disguise......of psychological reasons......of health, religious......all of them false...

The truth is that ablation, preferably practiced on girls aged 14 and even younger, can lead to death from hemorrhagic shock and, at best, cause and result in severe psychological sequelae due to the trauma.
From Europe, we must strive with all our might to eradicate this human rights violation that undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
This, ladies and gentlemen, is about abuse, cruelty, torture against girls. And this degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To achieve this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms available to our legal system, and I encourage our judges to take action to prevent genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who carry it out. Let European law speak with one voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I call on civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but many of us will not stop because we owe it to 70 million mutilated women.
Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons we approved the dairy package was precisely to adapt the sector towards a market without milk quotas by 2015.

But it is also true that with each approaching liberalization date, uncertainty in the sector grows due to the lack of a clear exit strategy. There is also a growing list of reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection from us in the face of the decision we must make.

Reasons, for example, such as the belief in maintaining vineyard planting rights or maintaining sugar quotas, at least until 2020. Reasons such as the uncertainty in the sector about the real effects of the dairy package and about whether

...by which time we will have had the opportunity to conduct a thorough assessment of these matters. ...and also due to uncertainties surrounding the future direction of the common agricultural policy, ...particularly its budget, that is, the portion of income ...which does not come from the markets and which impacts our producers.

Therefore, what are we asking of you, Commissioner? That you convey this to Mr. Cholos. That we do not pursue a piecemeal policy of dismantling our protection system without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

postpone the end of the quota until 2015, to a date that provides security to the sector and opens up an open and transparent debate on regulatory mechanisms, because markets are still more unfair and producers are increasingly more defenseless.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Many members of this Parliament have listened to the voice of the citizens, the voice of the street.

yes, it is an acceptable solution

The sense of impotence was so profound that Europe had to react as a matter of course. And it has done so for the benefit of all. Because the true winner of this past summit has been the euro.
And with this triumph, hope has returned that Europe will overcome its paralysis, moving from reflection to action.
At this summit, esteemed members, it was as necessary to adopt short-term measures to ensure financial stability as it was to implement long-term measures to address the shortcomings of the Union.
In this case, the immediate was indispensable to continue working in favor of what is important.
The imperative is to convey the message that the euro is a common, irrevocable, and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, decisions as important as empowering the European stability mechanism to directly recapitalize banks, which will break the vicious circle between banking debt and sovereign debt, a thesis, by the way, always defended by the current Spanish government.
Furthermore, it will serve to intervene in markets in support of the public debt of countries that meet their public deficit and reform commitments.
Those were necessary decisions to ensure financial stability, which should be the European Union's highest priority in the short term.
This is not the time, ladies and gentlemen, for certain countries to resort to nationalist maxims and place obstacles in the way.
I have already said it, it is time to bet on Europe.
Spain, ladies and gentlemen, is adopting and implementing, in record time, the most ambitious reform agenda in Spanish democracy, which includes a profound labor reform.
Furthermore, a financial reform is being implemented based on total transparency, thereby demonstrating its commitment to fiscal consolidation and meeting deficit targets.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process towards greater economic integration through four blocks: a banking union, a fiscal union, a framework for a common economic policy, and strengthening democratic agility.
Mr. President, the approach of the community, first and foremost, and then a European one, has always been not only to overcome crises, but to emerge strengthened from them.
I am glad that once again we are successful.
Dear colleagues, our attention is entirely focused on banks, which we continually hear described as the lifeblood of society.
It is likely that this image is accurate, but let us bear in mind that every body is supported by a spine and joints.
Well then, the backbone and joints of that social body we call Europe are precisely its transportation networks and its energy infrastructures.
It is essential, as has been stated this afternoon here in the chamber, to mobilize private financing and, if necessary, public financing.
And moreover, it is an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt guaranteed by European institutions specifically aimed at these purposes, and also open to any investor.
Congratulations to the speakers for their work and also to the Commission for its clear impetus to these projects.

Mr. President, dear Commissioner, Minister, in which I greet the new presidency, I am a veteran militant of the defunct non-aligned movement led by your country and which strongly desires the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

Honorable Members, the opportunity should be seized for a broader reform of the Court, perhaps, but the Commission's and my colleague's report's ambitions are very positive and should be supported with the unanimity it received in our Committee.
The agility and efficient functioning of the Court are fundamental... which I question with the new, today delayed, patent jurisdiction.
Congratulations to the speaker. Move forward with the court reform.

Thank you, President, Commissioner Reding. My country has experienced too many setbacks since the arrival of the Popular Party in government. Repeated and continuous attempts to roll back established rights, such as silencing those who dissent, including consumer organizations, among others.

Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, first of all, I would like to highlight the excellent work of Ms. Macagan, the rapporteur, and also the rest of the rapporteurs, in reaching this agreement.
agreement at first reading, which was very important as it brought into force the regulation we had adopted in 2010 and it was necessary to make some adjustments.
not because it was bad legislation, the legislation was very good, but as has been said, the recent events, well known to all, occurred and demonstrated that there was a certain
a gap that needed to be addressed to prevent its recurrence, and there was a need to strengthen specific aspects of the surveillance and security of medicines once they are placed on the market.

Therefore, from now on, as stated, holders of a marketing authorization for a medicine who do not renew, withdraw, or request the withdrawal or suspension of the authorization, will retain the authorization.
obligation to declare the real reasons and motives that have led to this withdrawal or the suspension of the authorization of a medicine.
This is a significant achievement in the interest of transparency and will prevent the holder of a marketing authorization from attempting to conceal the true reasons for their decision.
Moreover, in the event that any of these actions are carried out in a third country, all concerned Member States where this medicine is marketed must be informed.
Everything will enhance transparency and security without overly burdening the European Medicines Agency and national agencies.
The second significant amendment achieved is that all authorized products subject to a post-authorization safety study are automatically included in a list of products under this monitoring.
Lastly, we cannot forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role, and for this reason, this plenary should approve this proposal.

The work of the rapporteur, Mr. President, is very good, but I would like to take this opportunity to say here, in this context, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can observe.
We forget what Pufendorf already taught, that general laws should be few and their meaning must be correctly understood.
Therefore, those who promote it should use all the clarity that is possible.
And Montesquieu always insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
In other words, we must avoid esoteric jargon, filled with neologisms and unjustified linguistic borrowings, as it creates a sinister web where pitfalls lurk and arbitrariness prevails.
We address very complex matters in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to communicate them to the citizenry in a comprehensible and accessible manner.
It is common for even legal professionals themselves, judges, and lawyers to become despairing when faced with our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way to demonstrate respect for the citizen.

Thank you, Mr. President. Honorable members, there is an old principle that has transitioned from the legal to the political realm: pacta sunt servanda. In other words, agreements are meant to be honored.
By this, I refer to the significant measures adopted by the June European Council to address the crisis that affects us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased, and they have positively received decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro irreversibly.
The European Council, observed last week, contains, ladies and gentlemen, undeniable positive aspects. The conclusions regarding progress towards the Banking Union are satisfactory.
The A27 agreement for the establishment of the banking supervisor is also positive. Ultimately, it is appropriate to entrust the implementation to the Eurozone's Ministers of Economy.
But they will allow you to make a critical judgment based on the biased interpretations that have been unilaterally made of it.

It is not admissible, ladies and gentlemen, to make particular interpretations that could distort the mandate given to the Ministers of Economy. Likewise, we do not applaud the reporting of matters as agreements when they were not even discussed.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism that must cover all financial entities.

The financial crisis has intensified due to the existence of complex and exotic tradable securities linked to derivative instruments and over-the-counter transactions. All of this is driven by the pursuit of high returns at great speed.
It is necessary to bring financial operations into a transparent market to ensure the proper formation of prices and the competitiveness of tradable products.
But above all, it is indispensable that the information provided be understandable to investors, who must have full knowledge to freely consent to the risks they are assuming.
Transparency is of no use as a brilliant flash of light if the complexity in the configuration of negotiable products blinds the understanding of citizens.

President, today we are debating four reports that represent a revitalization of our common security and defense policy.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defense have a clear European dimension, in contrast to the minority and Euroskeptic sectors that also prevail in this Chamber.
The report by Mr. Danian, to whom I would like to express my gratitude for his consensus-seeking spirit during its preparation, contains significant contributions from the Socialist Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
And we would like to see these aspects included in the possible review of the European Defense Strategy.
We have also emphasized that a strong common security and defense policy is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another of the challenges that is taking on significant dimensions for our global security.
It is that of cybersecurity and cyber defense, reports that we also discuss today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis, where Member States are being forced to cut their defense budgets, it is when European protection projects are most needed.
That is why it is more important than ever to strengthen the role of the European Defence Agency, which is currently facing significant challenges.
I conclude by stating that we can relaunch European security and defense, and do so with President Ford Lapui's project for the Council in December 2013.
Many thanks to the four speakers.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, once again the defense of the general interests upheld by the Commission and Parliament is clashing with national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
With the prior acceptance of the legitimacy of both positions, it is inexcusable not to achieve a balance.
The relevance of the upcoming financial framework is undeniable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on their behalf, reiterate that the Presidency's proposal is, in our view, unacceptable.
A cut of 75 billion euros from the already inevitably meager proposal of the European Commission is sterile and useless.
And it is not just that. The new direct cut to agricultural and cohesion policies crosses the red line that Spain has been pointing out since the beginning of the works.
Ladies and Gentlemen, it is no longer the time to debate a supposed dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create jobs.
And with this budget, one does not get very far. Rather, it constitutes a missile to the waterline.
Ladies and Gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with far fewer resources, especially if what exists is distributed unjustly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that would simply mean the disappearance of growth opportunities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity. And this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, which deserves credit for its efforts in outlining a different approach.

At this juncture, in the face of the need for unity and shared efforts, I would like to thank Mr. Barroso for making a forceful statement the other day in Cádiz regarding the interpretation of the treaties in the event of a secessionist scenario within the Union.

made it clear, unequivocally, as the guardian of the treaties, that if a part of a Member State secedes as an independent state, it becomes considered a third country and, therefore, will not be affected in any way by the declarations and effects of the treaty itself.

I hope, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the Mr. President, that this can be taken up and that this safe and consistent doctrine of the commission can continue to remain alive for the assurance of all.
